CHAPTER 1. - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Scaffolds or ladders over streets or sidewalks, § 9-1006; objects on window ledges 
over sidewalks, § 9-1007. 


ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 


Sec. 3-1001. - Obstruction generally—Consent required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct, or cause to be obstructed, or permit the obstruction by 
any means or in any manner and to any extent, any public sidewalk, footway, public street or highway, 
public square, alley or other public place or grounds within the municipality for any purpose, without the 
consent of the manager. 


Sec. 3-1002. - Same—Removal required within time fixed or required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse or fail to remove, or cause to be removed, any 
obstruction on any street, highway or other public place within the time for which the manager may have 
given his permission for the obstruction thereof; or if no time is set when permission is given, the 
obstruction shall be removed within the time as the manager may require. 


Sec. 3-1003. - Same—Permanent obstruction prohibited. 
    No permission shall be granted for the placing of a permanent obstruction on any of the streets, 
highways or other public places. 


Sec. 3-1004. - Building materials in streets, sidewalks and public places—Permission required. 
    Building materials shall not be laid on any sidewalk, street or public place until the consent of the 
manager is first obtained; and it shall be the duty of the person desiring so to use the streets to inform the 
manager when permission is desired to lay material thereon, and otherwise to obstruct the places for the 
purpose of erecting a building adjoining the street, where some obstruction thereof is necessary, what 
space will be needed and for what length of time the obstruction will be necessary, and the manager shall 
then give permission accordingly, imposing then and from time to time, reasonable conditions as he may 
consider necessary or proper for the protection of the public and the public property. 


Sec. 3-1005. - Same—Protection by barricades, lights. 
    While the obstructions provided for herein remain on the streets, sidewalks or other public places, 
suitable safeguards by day and by night shall be maintained by the contractor, owner or person in charge 
of the work, for the protection of the public, by roping off, using lanterns and other proper means. 


Sec. 3-1006. - Same—Removal of conditions. 
    At the expiration of the time provided for herein, all obstructions, materials and trash or other things 
shall be removed by the owner or contractor and the street, sidewalk or public place shall be restored to 
as good condition in every respect as before the materials or other obstructions were laid thereon. 


Sec. 3-1007. - Display of merchandise on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to display goods, wares or merchandise on the sidewalks in front 
of his or her place of business without the approval of city council. 
(1962 Code, § 26-4; Ord. No. O-12-94, 7-12-94; Ord. No. O-18-94, 11-8-94) 


Sec. 3-1008. - Merchandise, etc., unloaded on sidewalks to be removed within one hour. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person receiving shipments of goods or merchandise, when it is 
necessary to unload them on the sidewalk in front of their place of business, to leave such goods, boxes, 
crates or merchandise to remain on the sidewalks more than one hour after their arrival. 
(1962 Code, § 26-5) 


Sec. 3-1009. - Overhanging obstructions. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to build or to extend on or over the streets or 
sidewalks within the city any awning, shelter, signboard or other structure without a permit from the 
city council. 
(b) ?All awnings, shelters, signboards or other structures built on or over the sidewalks within the city by 
permission of the city council shall be strongly and securely made, and safely built and fastened so 
that no danger to passersby will be suffered or threatened, shall in no way obstruct, hinder or 
interfere with the use of the sidewalk, and shall not have less than six (6) feet, ten (10) inches clear 
space above the sidewalk. 
(c) ?In the event any judgment should be secured against the city by reason of injury to person or 
property inflicted by the instrumentalities referred to herein, the city shall be entitled to recover 
against the person, firm or corporation owning or in control of the instrumentalities the amount of the 
judgment, together with interest thereon and its attorney fees incurred in connection with bringing 
action against the person, firm or corporation. 
(d) ?The city, neither by this section nor by the issue of any permit pursuant thereto nor by any other act 
on the part of itself or any of its officers, servants, agents or employees, represents or warrants to 
any member of the public the safety of any of the instrumentalities referred to in this section or 
waives any of its legal rights to contest or defend any action brought against it by reason of alleged 
defects in the instrumentalities, all of which rights are specifically reserved. 
(Ord. No. O-22-87, 11-24-87) 


Sec. 3-1010. - Protection and planting of trees and shrubs on public property. 
(a) ?No person, firm, or corporation shall cut, trim, prune, break, remove, climb, destroy, mutilate, or 
injure in any manner whatsoever, any tree or ornamental shrub located within the right-of-way of any 
public street or in any public park without the written authorization of the city manager or his 
designee. For purposes of this section, trees and ornamental shrubs located within the right-of-way 
of any public street or in any public park shall be termed "public trees." 
(b) ?Authorization to cut, trim, prune, or remove any public tree shall be in writing and shall detail the 
manner and extent to which the public tree(s) may be cut, trimmed, pruned, or removed. All pruning, 
cutting, trimming, and removal shall be done in accordance with any policies on tree trimming, 
pruning, and removal as adopted by the city and amended from time to time. 
(c) ?No person, firm, or corporation shall injure, misuse, or remove any device placed to protect public 
trees. 
(d) ?No person shall place any wire, rope, sign, poster, or other fixture on a public tree without the 
written authorization of the city manager or his designee. 
(e) ?Any person, firm, or corporation who shall cut, trim, prune, break, climb, mutilate or injure in any 
manner whatsoever, any public tree without first obtaining written authorization as provided in 
paragraph (b), shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided 
in section 1-3048. Each unauthorized cutting, trimming, injury, etc. shall be considered a separate 
offense for purposes of this section. 
(f) ?No tree or ornamental shrub shall be planted in the right-of-way of a public street without written 
authorization of the city manager or his designee and other governmental agencies, such as the 
South Carolina Department of Transportation, as appropriate. 
(g) ?Utility companies and governmental agencies are exempt from paragraphs (a) and (b) of this 
section provided that such agency has executed an annual agreement with the city under the 
provisions of section 5-6144(3). 
(Ord. No. O-01-81, §§ 1—3, 1-27-81; Ord. No. O-02-84, §§ 1—4, 2-28-84; Ord. No. O-08-95, 
5-9-95; Ord. No. O-11-97, 2-25-97) 
Cross reference— Provisions similar to subsection (a), above, § 3-2001(a); park and tree 
advisory commission, § 3-3001 et seq. 


Sec. 3-1011. - Construction of private driveways. 
(a) ?When a driveway entrance is constructed at the time a street is being paved and no sidewalk exists, 
the paving project would absorb the cost of paving the entrance way to the property line and if the 
paving of the street results in hazardous or difficult driving conditions the city will in normal 
circumstances grade the land of the abutting property so as to provide a proper and safe entrance. 
Paving of the driveway, however, will stop at the property line. 
(b) ?The city, in laying a sidewalk, will in all cases construct the sidewalk in such a manner as to provide 
a proper entrance into streets, with the cost thereof being borne by the sidewalk project. 
(c) ?When the city is requested by a property owner to break out an existing sidewalk not in need of 
repair and to reconstruct it so as to provide for a driveway, such cost will be borne entirely by the 
property owner. 
(d) ?When the city is requested by a property owner to break out an existing sidewalk in need of repair 
and to reconstruct it so as to provide for a driveway, the cost will be borne half by the city and half by 
the property owner. 
(e) ?The city shall not construct any sidewalk upon privately-owned property. 
(Code 1966, §§ 26-7—26-11) 


Sec. 3-1012. - Building and lot numbers. 
(a) ?All lots, parts of lots or other property abutting on any street, road, drive or thoroughfare shall be 
numbered. 
(b) ?Where King Street intersects Beaufort River on the east shall constitute the base line for all 
numbering on streets running east and west and where Carteret Street intersects Beaufort River on 
the south shall constitute the base line for all numbering on streets running north and south. 
(c) ?In the business district, from the corner of each block nearest its respective base line, each twenty 
(20) feet of frontage shall be given a number. 
(d) ?In the residential district, comprising all of the municipality outside of the business district, from the 
corner of each block nearest its respective base line, each forty (40) feet of frontage shall be given a 
number, except that where lots vary from forty (40) feet in width, such lots shall be numbered to 
conform to the size of lots. 
(e) ?On all streets the lot numbers shall run consecutively, alternating from side to side. Odd numbers 
shall be on the north side of the streets running east and west and on the east side of the streets 
running north and south. The numbers shall run one hundred to each block or distance between two 
(2) street intersections on the same street. Where streets intersect, but do not cross, the numbers 
shall run in each case to a street intersecting on both sides of the street being numbered. The 
respective blocks located on the streets which do not intersect the base lines shall bear the hundred 
number of the corresponding block nearest the same location on the nearest street, extending in the 
same direction which does intersect the base line. 
(f) ?Upon application, the city manager shall assign the proper number to any lot or building. In case of 
doubt or where a question arises the city manager shall decide the question and fix the number of 
such lot or building. 
(g) ?All buildings now or hereafter erected or fronting on any street, road, drive or thoroughfare shall 
have conspicuously placed on such building the number as provided by this article. 
(h) ?The number plate placed on any building shall be of metal or wood, or the number may be painted 
on the front of the building, door, post, transom or other place. The numbers shall be at least three 
(3) inches in height and shall be so located as to be readily visible from the street. 
(1962 Code, §§ 26-12, 26-19) 


Sec. 3-1013. - Paving streets. 
    Upon petition by two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the abutting property owners, streets shall be paved by the city, 
charging as a property assessment one-half (½) of the total cost thereof to be against the abutting 
property. Such assessment shall be spread over a three-year period on the tax assessment levy of that 
property, and a discount of five (5) percent shall be given all property holders paying the assessment 
within sixty (60) days. 
(Code 1967, § 26-1) 


Sec. 3-1014. - Storage of vehicles on streets for more than twenty-four hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any vehicle owned by him or in his custody to occupy the 
streets for more than twenty-four (24) hours. 


Sec. 3-1015. - Removal of branches and trees on private property. 
(a) ?The city shall have the authority to prune or remove branches or trees on private property which: 
(1) ?Substantially block light from a street lamp; 
(2) ?Block visibility in a required sight triangle at an intersection; 
(3) ?Are dead or diseased and overhang a public way; 
(4) ?Are otherwise hazardous to the public. 
(b) ?The city shall notify those property owners in writing of the need to prune or remove the branches or 
trees. If the property owner does not remove the branch of tree in thirty (30) days then the city shall 
have the authority to remove it and charge the cost to the owner. Any pruning or removal shall be 
done according to accepted arboricultural standards. 
(c) ?Where there is an imminent threat to public safety the city shall have the authority to remove the 
branch or tree immediately. The city shall attempt to notify the property owner prior to removing the 
branch or tree. If the property owner is not notified at that time the city shall notify him within twenty-
four (24) hours of the action taken and the reason for the action. 
(Ord. No. O-8-95, 5-9-95) 


Sec. 3-1016. - Encroachment permits. 
(a) ?Permit requirement. No person shall construct, excavate, or plant within or upon any land or real 
property owned or substantially controlled by the city, nor shall any person in any other manner 
materially impact such property below the surface, at the surface, or above the surface of the 
ground, without first obtaining an encroachment permit authorizing such activity from the city. 
(b) ?Application process. An application for an encroachment permit may be obtained at the city 
department of public works. The applicant shall complete the application and furnish any other 
information, plans, and documentation as may be required by the director of public works. Upon 
receipt of an application the director of public works shall forward copies of the application to the city 
manager, other interested department heads, and other interested parties. The director of public 
works shall in a timely manner approve, approve with conditions, or deny the application in 
accordance with reasonable standards and criteria. In situations where it appears that modifications 
sought by an applicant could have significant impact upon land or property owned or substantially 
controlled by the city, the director of public works shall forward the application to city council for 
review and approval. 
(c) ?Bonding. Prior to issuance of an encroachment permit the applicant shall execute and deposit with 
the director of public works a good and sufficient escrow or an unconditional, irrevocable letter of 
credit. This instrument shall be in such an amount as may be required to insure completion of the 
project or to restore the land or property to a comparable condition to what it was prior to the 
commencement of any work, as appropriate, in the event that the applicant does not complete the 
project according to approved plans in the specified timeframe. The director of public works may 
waive this requirement where the impact upon the city's land or property is minimal or where other 
acceptable arrangements may be made. Upon completion of the work as approved the director of 
public works shall release the escrow to the applicant or terminate the letter of credit on behalf of the 
applicant. 
(d) ?Policies and procedures. The director of public works shall promulgate policies and procedures for 
review, approval, and administration of encroachment permits subject to approval by the city 
manager. 
(e) ?Appeal. Any person aggrieved by any decision of the director of public works regarding an 
encroachment permit may appeal to the city manager provided such appeal is filed within thirty (30) 
days of notification of the decision. 
(Ord. No. O-06-96, 2-27-96) 


Secs. 3-1017—3-1020. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE B. - EXCAVATIONS 


Sec. 3-1021. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig any ditch, excavation, hole or opening in any street, 
sidewalk or public place without the permission of the council, or the manager. Permission shall not be 
granted until the purpose for which it is to be made or dug shall be made known, and then the ditch, 
excavation, hole or opening shall be used for the purpose so declared and no other. 


Sec. 3-1022. - Protection by barricades, lights, etc. 
    Every ditch, excavation, hole or opening in any street, sidewalk or public place, no matter for what 
purpose made, shall be securely and safely covered over with boards or other suitable material, or 
enclosed in a secure way as to prevent accidents to persons, animals and vehicles, both during the night 
and day, when the workmen are not engaged thereon; and during the night lanterns shall be kept burning 
at these places as a signal of danger to all pedestrians and drivers. 


Sec. 3-1023. - Restoration of surface. 
    Every ditch, excavation, hole or opening in any street, sidewalk or public place, shall be as speedily 
filled as possible, and shall not be kept open longer than is absolutely necessary. The street, sidewalk or 
public place shall be restored to as good condition with as good materials as existing before the ditch, 
excavation, hole or opening was made. 


Secs. 3-1024—3-1030. - Reserved. 


CHAPTER 2. - PARKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-7-13, adopted Aug. 13, 2013, repealed the former Ch. 2, § 3-2001, and 
enacted a new Ch. 2 as set out herein. The former Ch. 2 pertained to similar subject matter. See the 
Code Comparative Table for a complete history of former Ch. 2. 
Cross reference— Vendors in parks, § 7-1001; trespass on municipal grounds, § 7-6012; skateboard, 
etc., on sidewalks near parks, § 8-5002; loitering in parks, § 9-1002; camping in vehicles in parks, § 9-
1003. 


Sec. 3-2001. - Prohibited and regulated acts in all city parks. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to pick, cut, uproot, dig up, break, remove or in any way injure, 
damage or destroy any plant, shrub, grass, flower, or tree growing within the limits of any public park 
of the city. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to pasture, graze, under any condition, any cows, mules, horses, 
sheep, goats, hogs or cattle of any kind within the limits of any public park of the city or to allow of 
the aforesaid animals to wander through or stray into a park or parks at any time whatsoever. 
(c) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to damage, injure or deface any building, bench, fence or other 
structure within any park. 
(d) ?It shall be unlawful to remove dirt or topsoil from any park. 
(e) ?It shall be unlawful to intentionally or carelessly scatter trash, cigarette butts, debris, paper or litter of 
any kind in any park. Refuse, trash, cigarette butts and other waste material must be properly 
disposed of in trash receptacles or recycling containers. Trash receptacles are for the use of the 
general public and shall not be used by event organizers for the disposal of event trash. 
(f) ?The owner and/or persons having custody of animals shall be responsible for the removal of any 
excreta deposited in any park. 
(g) ?It shall be unlawful to start any fire or to grill any food in any park except in conjunction with events 
specifically approved in writing by the city. 
(h) ?It shall be unlawful to release balloons of any type at city parks or on any city property. 
(i) ?It shall be unlawful to consume alcohol in any park except in conjunction with an event specifically 
approved in writing by the city and where the consumption of alcohol is specifically approved in 
writing. 
(j) ?It shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle in any park except in designated parking areas except in 
conjunction with events specifically approved in writing by the city. 
(k) ?It shall be unlawful to operate a motorized vehicle upon walkways, sidewalks, or grounds within any 
park with the following exceptions: motorized wheelchairs; public safety and public maintenance 
equipment; and in conjunction with an event specifically approved in writing by the city. 
(l) ?All animals shall be on leashes that are no more than six (6) feet long except within fenced areas in 
approved dog parks. 
(Ord. No. O-7-13, 8-13-13) 


Sec. 3-2002. - Henry C. Chambers Waterfront Park. 
(a) ?Recognizing the unique construction of the seawall and marina facilities and high speed of tide flow, 
it shall be unlawful to dive from, or swim adjacent to, the seawall of the Henry C. Chambers Park or 
the Downtown Marina. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any boat, sailing vessel or other watercraft to anchor or moor within two 
hundred (200) feet of, or to, any of the city-owned mooring buoys located in the Beaufort River 
immediately west of the downtown marina without permission of or authorization from the downtown 
marina operator. No more than one boat, sailing vessel or watercraft shall be moored to each buoy 
or tied in tandem. 
(c) ?It shall be unlawful for all vessels to anchor, raft to, moor or tie up overnight to the seawall of the 
Henry C. Chambers Park without the permission of the general manager of the Downtown Marina. 
No vessel shall anchor, raft to, moor or tie up to the seawall of the Henry C. Chambers Park in 
excess of three (3) days or seventy-two (72) hours. At the discretion of the city manager, the time 
may be extended. A docking fee of fifty cents ($0.50) per linear foot shall be levied to all vessels. 
Water and electric services shall not be furnished by the city except by special permission of the city 
manager, through arrangement with the general manager of the Downtown Marina, in which case a 
fee covering the cost of providing such services shall be levied. No charge shall be levied for daytime 
docking or mooring to the seawall for noncommercial vessels. 
(d) ?In the interest of water safety and to ensure protection of the facilities and ecological environment of 
the Henry C. Chambers Park and the Downtown Marina, the following rules shall apply: 
(1) ?Any damage to the seawall as a result of a vessel docking, rafting, mooring or anchoring shall 
be the responsibility of the boat owner. 
(2) ?No activity may be engaged in or conducted from any vessel which infringes on the seawall, 
sidewalk or the park. Furthermore, the Federal Water Pollution Control Act prohibits the 
discharge of oil or oily waste into or upon the navigable waters of the United States or the 
waters of the contiguous zone if such discharge causes a film or sheen upon or a discoloration 
of the surface of the water or causes a sludge or emulsion beneath the surface of the water. 
Violators are subject to a penalty of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(3) ?No boat, vessel or watercraft will be tied or moored or other than the cleats or rings provided 
for such. The mooring to the chains or lifelines between the pillars is forbidden. 
(4) ?It shall be unlawful for any boat, sailing vessel or other watercraft to anchor or moor in the 
Beaufort River within two hundred (200) feet of the seawall of the Henry C. Chambers Park. 
(e) ?The city council may restrict and/or designate areas for docking or mooring and may waive the fees 
for docking or mooring to the seawall in the Henry C. Chambers Park during special events in the 
park or at such other times as may be necessary. 
(f) ?It shall be unlawful to ride a bicycle, moped, motorbike, motorcycle or other motorized device upon 
the walkways, sidewalks, grounds or otherwise within the bounds of the Henry C. Chambers Park, 
unless special permission is granted for events requiring such. Police vehicles and city maintenance 
vehicles are excluded from the prohibitions of this subsection. 
(g) ?It shall be unlawful to operate, or to conduct a business that involves the operation or rental of, 
personal watercraft or the operation of a business involving bungee jumping at or from the downtown 
marina. For purposes of this section, "personal watercraft" shall include wave runners, jet skis, board 
sailing, and parasailing. 
(h) ?Prohibited and regulated acts concerning the Marina Day Dock. 
(1) ?It shall be unlawful for all vessels, except a dinghy, to anchor, raft to, moor or tie up to, the 
Marina Day Dock between the hours of 1:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m., seven (7) days a week. A dinghy 
may tie to the north (inland) side of the Marina Day Dock, twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven 
(7) days a week. For the purpose of this article, a "dinghy" is defined as a small boat or 
inflatable raft used as a tender as to a yacht or larger water craft. The registered owner of 
vessels found in violation of this section shall be held responsible. 
(2) ?It shall be unlawful for any boat, sailing vessel, or other watercraft to anchor or moor in the 
Beaufort River within two hundred (200) feet of the Marina Day Dock. 
(3) ?Any damage to the Day Dock as a result of a vessel docking, rafting, mooring, or anchoring 
shall be the responsibility of the boat owner. 
(4) ?The city council may waive the docking and use of the Marina Day Dock during special events 
or at such times as may be necessary. 
(5) ?It shall be unlawful for any vessel to anchor, raft to, moor, or tie up to the Marina Day Dock for 
the purpose of repairs. Other acts prohibited at the Marina Day Dock are the operation of 
commercial activities. 
(Ord. No. O-7-13, 8-13-13) 


Sec. 3-2003. - Spanish Moss Trail. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful to operate a motorized vehicle on the trail, except for motorized wheelchairs, and 
public safety and public maintenance equipment. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful to be on the trail before dawn and after dusk. 
(c) ?The speed limit on the trail shall be fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
(d) ?All animals shall be on leashes that are no more than six (6) feet long. 
(e) ?Fishing shall only be allowed in designated areas. 
(f) ?It shall be unlawful to use the trail for club and organizational events without written approval of the 
city. 
(g) ?Horses are prohibited on the trail. 
(Ord. No. O-7-13, 8-13-13) 


Sec. 3-2004. - Penalties. 
(a) ?Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, shall be 
prosecuted according to the procedures established under section 1-3048(a), (b), and (c) for 
misdemeanors, and upon conviction, shall be fined as determined by the court for each offense. 
(b) ?Nothing herein contained shall prevent the city from taking such other lawful action as is necessary 
to prevent or remedy any violation. 
(Ord. No. O-7-13, 8-13-13) 


CHAPTER 3. - PARK AND TREE ADVISORY COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-10-14, adopted April 22, 2016, repealed the former Ch. 3, §§ 3-3001—3-
3010, and enacted a new Ch. 3 as set out herein. The former Ch. 3 pertained to the tree board and 
derived from Ord. No. O-05-83, §§ 1—9, adopted April 26, 1983; Ord. No. O-20-83, § 1, adopted Dec. 13, 
1983; Ord. No. O-26-90, adopted Oct. 23, 1990; Ord. No. O-08-95, adopted May 22, 1995; Ord. No. O-
43-01, adopted Sept. 25, 2001; and Ord. No. O-25-04, adopted Sept. 14, 2004. 
Cross reference— Protection of trees, § 3-1010; protection of trees in parks, § 3-2001(a). 


Sec. 3-3001. - Definitions. 
    Street trees are herein defined as all woody vegetation located in the right-of-way of all publicly-
owned streets within the city. 
    Park trees are herein defined as all woody vegetation which is located in publicly-owned parks and 
open spaces within the city. 
(Ord. No. O-10-14, 4-22-14) 


Sec. 3-3002. - Creation and establishment of board. 
    There is hereby created and established the park and tree advisory commission for the city, which 
shall consist of five (5) members who are either residents of the city, own property within the city, or either 
hold, or are associated with a business that holds a current city business license. Members shall be 
appointed by the city council. The park and tree advisory commission shall include one certified arborist, 
two (2) design professionals and two (2) citizen representatives. 
(Ord. No. O-10-14, 4-22-14) 


Sec. 3-3003. - Terms. 
    All terms shall be for three (3) years. At the end of a term, city council may re-appoint a commission 
member for another term. Council retains the authority to remove any member of the commission for 
cause. In the event a vacancy occurs during the term of any member, a successor shall be appointed by 
city council and begin a three-year term from date of initial appointment. 
(Ord. No. O-10-14, 4-22-14) 


Sec. 3-3004. - Compensation. 
    Members of the commission shall serve without compensation. Members may be reimbursed for 
actual expenses incurred in the performance of their duties from available funds approved in advance by 
the administrator. 
(Ord. No. O-10-14, 4-22-14) 


Sec. 3-3005. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the commission to develop and periodically update, an urban forestry 
management plan which supplements and corresponds to the recommendations of the civic master plan 
for the city. The management plan shall define the species of trees to be utilized as street and park trees 
and specify horticultural requirements for the planting, maintenance and preservation of public trees. 
Further, the commission shall study, investigate and make recommendations to council regarding park 
design, acquisition and/or de-acquisition of city parks and open spaces, the planting of utility corridors, 
the design and maintenance of city playgrounds and recreation areas, the establishment of agricultural 
and public gardens in city parks and the creation and management of city trails and trail linkages. The 
commission shall also provide guidelines for the establishment of a city tree fund and make 
recommendations to city council for the prioritized allocation of monies. 
(Ord. No. O-10-14, 4-22-14) 


Sec. 3-3006. - Operation. 
    The commission shall elect a chairperson and a vice-chairperson from its members who shall serve 
for one year or until reelected, or until a successor is elected. The commission shall make its own rules 
and regulations and keep minutes of its proceedings. A majority of the seated members shall constitute a 
quorum for the transaction of business. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public. 
(Ord. No. O-10-14, 4-22-14) 


Sec. 3-3007. - Accessory duties. 
    The commission shall be responsible for the planning and procurements necessary for the annual 
Arbor Day celebration, the retrieval of required data for recertification as a Tree City USA by the Arbor 
Day Foundation from city public works, parks and planning departments, provision of park names for city 
council consideration in the naming/renaming of parks, and shall review appeals of any ruling by the city 
arborist in regards to denial of tree removal applications on private property. Further, the commission may 
notify private property owners, in writing, of any tree(s) on their property which pose a potential hazard to 
the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. O-10-14, 4-22-14) 


Sec. 3-3008. - Review by city council. 
    The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the park and tree 
advisory commission. Any person may appeal any ruling of the commission to the city council who may 
hear the matter and make final disposition of same. 
(Ord. No. O-10-14, 4-22-14) 


Secs. 3-3009—3-3099. - Reserved. 


CHAPTER 4. - CEMETERIES 


Sec. 3-4001. - Rates for grave spaces in city-owned or maintained cemetery. 
(a) ?For persons who own taxable property within the city and who have immediate relatives now buried 
in the cemetery, five dollars ($5.00) per square foot. 
(b) ?For persons who do not own taxable property within the city and who now have immediate relatives 
buried in the cemetery, six dollars ($6.00) per square foot. 
(c) ?No charge shall be made for indigents residing in the city. 
(Ord. No. O-32-97, 9-23-97) 


Sec. 3-4002. - Sale of grave spaces in city-owned or maintained cemetery. 
    Sale of spaces shall be limited to those persons having immediate relatives now buried in the 
cemetery. 
(Ord. of 5-?-65; Ord. No. O-32-97, 9-23-97)

events or occasions and in emergencies.

CHAPTER 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 


Sec. 4-1001. - Mandatory connection. 
    In accordance with the polices of Beaufort-Jasper Water and Sewer Authority, every building located 
within the City is required to connect to a water main operated and maintained by Beaufort-Jasper Water 
and Sewer Authority and to a sewer main operated and maintained by Beaufort-Jasper Water and Sewer 
Authority. 
(Ord. No. O-13-01, 2-27-01) 


CHAPTER 5. - ELECTRIC 


ARTICLE A. - UNDERGROUND UTILITY DISTRICTS 


Sec. 4-5001. - Designation of underground utility districts. 
    The city council shall from time to time by ordinance designate and extend underground utility 
districts within the city. 
(Ord. No. O-09-00, 3-28-2000) 


Sec. 4-5002. - Relocation of overhead wires in district. 
    When any street or portion thereof is designated as an underground utility district or as a part of an 
existing underground utility district, any person owning or maintaining overhead wires, associated 
overhead structures, or poles serving the same in such street or portion thereof, shall remove such wires, 
associated structures and poles as provided in section 4-5005. 
(Ord. No. O-09-00, 3-28-2000) 


Sec. 4-5003. - Limitations on new above-surface installations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, maintain or use any pole, overhead wires or 
associated structure within an underground utility district, excepting such poles as are necessary to 
support street lighting, traffic signals, and transmission lines above forty-three thousand (43,000) volts, 
after the date when such utilities are required to have been removed, or after a reasonable period of time 
after the designation by city council of an underground utility district or the extension of an existing district. 
(Ord. No. O-09-00, 3-28-2000) 


Sec. 4-5004. - Notice of district establishment to utility companies and property owners. 
    Within thirty (30) days after the establishment of an underground utility district, the city clerk shall 
mail a notice of such action to all affected utilities and to all persons owning real estate in the affected 
area. Such notice shall be directed to the last known address of such utility or property owner, as shown 
on the records of the county tax assessor. Such notice shall advise property owners that overhead wires, 
poles, and associated structures are to be removed, and if such property owners or their tenants desire to 
continue to receive utility service or services, such property owners shall at their expense make the 
necessary modifications to facilities on their property in order to receive such underground service from 
the utilities' specified terminal point. If no other changes are made in owner's facilities, then only that 
portion being modified to receive underground service shall be upgraded to conform to the city electrical 
code. 
(Ord. No. O-09-00, 3-28-2000) 


Sec. 4-5005. - Adaptation of service facilities of structure by property owner. 
    All conduits, conductors and associated equipment necessary to receive utility service between the 
service facilities of the supply utility and the service facilities to the structure being served shall be 
provided by the person owning such property. Such required construction shall be accomplished within 
ninety (90) days after the installation of the utility's facilities, i.e., supply line(s), conduit, and vaults. 
(Ord. No. O-09-00, 3-28-2000) 


Sec. 4-5006. - Discontinuance of service to premises for noncompliance. 
    If the property owner does not comply with section 4-5005 within the time specified therein, the 
codes enforcement division shall have authority to order disconnection and removal of any and all poles, 
overhead wires or associated overhead structures supplying utility service to such property and the utility 
shall not be required thereafter to provide service to such premises, until the owner makes the necessary 
changes. 
(Ord. No. O-09-00, 3-28-2000) 


Sec. 4-5007. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article or failing to comply with any order issued pursuant 
hereto shall be punished as provided in section 1-3048 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. O-09-00, 3-28-2000)

CHAPTER 1. - BUILDING REGULATION AND CODE ENFORCEMENT 


ARTICLE A. - BUILDING 


Sec. 5-1001. - Fire districts. 
    The city shall be divided into the following fire districts: 
(1) ?Fire districts no. 1. Fire district no. 1 shall consist of an area beginning at the northwest corner 
of Craven and New Streets, thence south to the Beaufort River, thence west along the Beaufort 
River to a point where Newcastle Street extended would intersect with the Beaufort River, 
thence in a northerly direction along the western right-of-way of Newcastle Street to Craven 
Street, thence east along the northern right-of-way of Craven Street to the point of beginning. 
(2) ?Reserved. 
(1962 Code, § 8-9; Ord. No. O-05-03, 2-11-03) 
State Law reference— S.C. Code 5-25-20. 


Sec. 5-1002. - Building code adopted. 
    A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the Building Codes Office of the City of 
Beaufort, being marked and designated as the International Building Code, as published by the 
International Code Council, Inc., and any revisions thereof when received by the City of Beaufort, be and 
is hereby adopted as the Building Code of the City of Beaufort, South Carolina, for the control of building 
and structures as provided herein; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions 
and terms of said building code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out 
in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 5-1003 of 
this article. 
(Ord. No. O-25-02, § 1, 6-25-02; Ord. No. O-22-08, § 1, 7-15-08) 


Sec. 5-1003. - Additions, insertions, deletions and changes. 
(a) ?Section 101.1 Title, of the International Building Code shall read: "These regulations shall be known 
as the Building Code of the City of Beaufort hereinafter referred to as 'this Code'." 
(b) ?Section 103.1 Creation of enforcement agency, of the International Building Code shall read: "The 
Building Codes Office is hereby created and the official in charge thereof shall be known as the 
building official." 
(c) ?Section 103.2 Appointment, of the International Building Code shall read: "The building official shall 
be appointed by the City Manager." 
(d) ?Section 105.2 Work exempt from Permit, of the International Building Code shall read as follows: 
105.2 Work exempt from permit. Exemptions from permit requirements of this code shall not be 
deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the provisions of 
this code or any other laws or ordinances of this jurisdiction. Permits shall not be required for the 
following: 
Building: 
1. ?Retaining walls on single-family residential property outside the Historic District that are not over 
4 feet (1,219 mm) in height measured from the bottom of the footing to the top of the wall, 
unless supporting a surcharge or impounding Class I, II or IIIA liquids. 
2. ?Interior residential remodeling including painting, doors, papering, tiling, nets, counter tops and 
similar finish work. 
3. ?Temporary motion picture, television and theater stage sets and scenery. 
4. ?Prefabricated swimming pools on single-family residential property outside the Historic District 
that are less than 24 inches (610 mm) deep, do not exceed 5,000 gallons (18,925 L) and are 
installed entirely above ground. 
5. ?Shade cloth structures constructed for nursery or agricultural purposes, not including service 
systems. 
6. ?Swings and other playground equipment accessory to detached one- and two-family dwellings. 
7. ?Window awnings if supported by an exterior wall, screens, and screen doors on single-family 
residential property outside the Historic District and do not require additional support of Group 
R-3 and U occupancies. 
8. ?Movable cases, racks, counters and partitions not over 5 feet 9 inches (1,753 mm) in height. 
Electrical: 
Repairs and maintenance: Minor repair work, including the replacement of lamps or the 
connection of approved portable electrical equipment to approved permanently installed 
receptacles. 
Radio and television transmitting stations: The provisions of this code shall not apply to 
electrical equipment used for radio and television transmissions, but do apply to equipment and 
wiring for a power supply and the installations of towers and antennas. 
Temporary testing systems: A permit shall not be required for the installation of any temporary 
system required for the testing or servicing of electrical equipment or apparatus. 
Gas: 
1. ?Portable heating appliance. 
2. ?Replacement of any minor part that does not alter approval of equipment or make such 
equipment unsafe. 
Mechanical: 
1. ?Portable heating appliance. 
2. ?Portable ventilation equipment. 
3. ?Portable cooling unit. 
4. ?Steam, hot or chilled water piping within any heating or cooling equipment regulated by this 
code. 
5. ?Replacement of any part that does not alter its approval or make it unsafe. 
6. ?Portable evaporative cooler. 
7. ?Self-contained refrigeration system containing 10 pounds (5 kg) or less of refrigerant and 
actuated by motors of 1 horsepower (746 W) or less. 
Plumbing: 
1. ?The stopping of leaks in drains, water, soil, waste or vent pipe, provided, however, that if any 
concealed trap, drain pipe, water, soil, waste or vent pipe becomes defective and it becomes 
necessary to remove and replace the same with new material, such work shall be considered as 
new work and a permit shall be obtained and inspection made as provided in this code. 
2. ?The clearing of stoppages or the repairing of leaks in pipes, valves or fixtures and the removal 
and reinstallation of water closets, provided such repairs do not involve or require the 
replacement or rearrangement of valves, pipes or fixtures. 
(e) ?Section 108.2 Schedule of Permit Fees, of the International Building Code shall read: "The fees for 
building permits and other related services shall be as provided in the City of Beaufort Building 
Codes Fee Schedule." 
(f) ?Section 1612.3 Establishment of Flood Hazard Area, of the International Building Code shall read: 
"The City of Beaufort hereby adopts the 'Flood Insurance Study for Beaufort County, South Carolina, 
and incorporated areas,' dated September 29, 1986, and establishes areas of special flood hazard 
as identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in an engineering report entitled 'The 
Flood Insurance Study for Beaufort County, South Carolina, and incorporated areas, dated 
September 29, 1986' as amended or revised, with the accompanying Flood Insurance Rate Maps 
(FIRM) and Flood Boundary and Floodway Maps (FBFM) and related supporting data along with any 
revisions thereto. The adopted flood hazard maps and supporting data are hereby adopted by 
reference and declared to be part of this section." 
(g) ?Section 3410.2 Applicability, of the International Building Code, shall read: "Structures existing prior 
to July 1, 2008, in which there is work involving additions, alterations, or changes of occupancy, shall 
be made to conform to the requirements of this section or the provisions of Sections 3403 through 
3407. The provisions in Sections 3410.2.1 through 3410.2.5 shall apply to existing occupancies that 
will continue to be, or are proposed to be, in Groups A, B, E, F, M, R, S and U. These provisions 
shall not apply to buildings with occupancies in Group H or I." 
(Ord. No. O-25-02, § 1, 6-25-02; Ord. No. O-02-05, § 1, 1-11-05; Ord. No. O-22-08, § 2, 7-15-
08) 


Sec. 5-1004. - Permit fees. 
(a) ?The rates, charges and fees for issuing of building, plumbing, mechanical, fuel gas, residential, 
private sewage disposal, electrical and fire permits, and other permits required by the city for 
construction, alteration, removal or improvements of buildings and structures and other charges 
within the City of Beaufort, and as heretofore required by the City of Beaufort under the provisions of 
the above codes, and other ordinances, shall be established from time to time by the City Council for 
the City of Beaufort, and a copy of the City of Beaufort Fee Schedule shall be on file in the offices of 
the building official and the city clerk. 
(b) ?The planning director has the authority to waive permit fees for demolition or improvement of 
structures on the Vacant or Abandoned Structures Inventory maintained by the Department of 
Planning and Development Services. 
(Ord. No. O-02-05, § 2, 1-11-05) 


Sec. 5-1005. - Reduction in fees and regulatory requirements for qualified affordable housing 
developments. 
(a) ?Building permit fees. Building permit fees shall be reduced up to a maximum of fifty (50) percent for 
any single or multifamily residential development, whether new construction or rehabilitation, that 
receives or will receive affordable housing financial assistance from any governmental or legally 
established nonprofit entity. Proof of qualification shall consist of legally executed documents 
establishing the financial assistance. No reduction shall be provided if work is undertaken without a 
permit. If the developer receives a reduction for any units which are ultimately not rented or sold to 
persons who are deemed low income, then the developer shall rebate to the city any savings which 
were incorrectly associated with those units. 
(b) ?Affordable housing standards established. Affordable housing is defined as a development with 
residential units available for rental or for sale to persons or families of low income defined as 
income equal to or less than eighty (80) percent of the area median income. Area median income is 
determined by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
(c) ?Fee schedule. Building permit fee reduction shall be calculated as follows: 
(1) ?Rental residential. A scaling percentage based upon the percentage of units within the 
development which are reserved for qualifying individuals or households shall be used as 
follows:

(Ord. No. O-02-05, § 2, 1-11-05) 


Sec. 5-1005.1. - Building board of appeals established. 
    There is hereby established in the city a board to be called the building board of appeals, which shall 
consist of five (5) members. The board shall consist of individuals who are qualified by experience and 
training to pass on matters pertaining to building construction. It is preferable that the board be composed 
of one architect, one engineer, one general contractor, and two (2) subcontractors such as electrical, 
plumbing, or gas contractors. The board shall be appointed by the city council. 
(1962 Code, § 8-3; Ord. No. O-02-05, § 2, 1-11-05; Ord. No. O-20-14, 7-22-14) 


Sec. 5-1005.2. - Terms of members. 
    All terms shall be for four (4) years. At the end of a term, city council may re-appoint a board member 
for additional terms. Members shall continue to serve until their successors are appointed. In the event a 
vacancy occurs during the term of any member, a successor shall be appointed by city council and begin 
a four-year term from date of initial appointment. 
(1962 Code, § 8-4; Ord. No. O-02-05, § 2, 1-11-05; Ord. No. O-20-14, 7-22-14) 


Sec. 5-1006. - Duties generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the building board of appeals to hear appeals and perform other duties, all of 
which are imposed upon it by the various parts of the building code as well as such other duties that may 
be imposed upon it by the city council. 
(1962 Code, § 8-5; Ord. No. O-20-14, 7-22-14) 


Sec. 5-1007. - Quorum; number of votes required for affirmative action. 
    A majority of the seated members of the building board of appeals shall constitute a quorum. The 
concurring vote of three (3) members of the building board of appeals shall be necessary to decide in 
favor of the applicant on any matter brought before the board. No board member shall act in a case in 
which he has a personal interest. 
(1962 Code, § 8-6(Ord. No. O-20-14, 7-22-14) 


Sec. 5-1008. - Secretary. 
    The building board of appeals shall designate a person to serve as secretary of the board and such 
secretary shall make a detailed record of all its proceedings, which shall set forth the reasons for its 
decisions, the votes of each member participating therein, the absence of any member and any failure of 
any member to vote. 
(1962 Code, § 8-7; Ord. No. O-20-14, 7-22-14) 


Sec. 5-1009. - Promulgation of rules and regulations. 
    The building board of appeals shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedure not 
inconsistent with the provisions of this article or the various parts of the building code. The board shall 
meet when necessary. 
(1962 Code, § 8-8; Ord. No. O-20-14, 7-22-14) 


Sec. 5-1010. - Duties of building board of appeals generally. 
    The building board of appeals as established by sections 5-1004 to 5-1009 shall faithfully perform 
the duties imposed upon it by the provisions of this article. 
(1962 Code, § 8-46) 


Sec. 5-1011. - Appeals from decision of the building official; grounds. 
    Whenever the building official shall reject or refuse to approve the mode or manner of a proposed 
gas installation, or materials to be used in the installation, or when it is claimed that the provisions of this 
article do not apply, or that an equally good or more desirable form of installation can be employed in any 
specific case, or when it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of this article or any of the regulations 
hereunder have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the owner of the building or structure or his 
duly authorized agent, may appeal from the decision of the building official to the building board of 
appeals. 
(1962 Code, § 8-47) 


Sec. 5-1012. - Time limit. 
(a) ?Notice of appeal shall be in writing and filed within thirty (30) days after the decision is rendered by 
the building official. 
(b) ?In case of an installation which, in the opinion of the building official, is unsafe or dangerous, the 
building official may, on his order, limit the time for such appeal to a shorter period. 
(1962 Code, § 8-48; Ord. No. O-20-14, 7-22-14) 


Sec. 5-1013. - Procedure generally; what decision to specify. 
(a) ?The building board of appeals, when so appealed to, and after a hearing, may vary the application 
of any provision of this article to any particular case when, in its opinion, the interpretation of the 
building official should be modified or reversed. 
(b) ?A decision of the building board of appeals to modify an order of the building official shall specify in 
what manner such modification is made, the condition upon which it is made, and the reasons 
therefor. 
(1962 Code, § 8-49; Ord. No. O-20-14, 7-22-14) 


Sec. 5-1014. - Decisions generally. 
(a) ?Every decision of the building board of appeals shall be final; subject, however, to such remedy as 
an aggrieved party might have at law or in equity. It shall be in writing and shall indicate the vote 
upon the decision. Every decision shall be promptly filed in the office of the building official, and shall 
be open to public inspection, a certified copy shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant and a 
copy shall be publicly posted in the office of the building official for two (2) weeks after filing. 
(b) ?The building board of appeals shall, in every case, reach a decision as soon as possible but not 
later than ten (10) days after the appeal. 
(c) ?If a decision of the building board of appeals reverses or modifies a refusal, order, or disallowance 
of the building official, the building official shall immediately take action in accordance with such 
decision. 
(Ord. No. O-20-14, 7-22-14) 


Sec. 5-1015. - Residential code for one- and two-family dwellings adopted. 
    A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office in the Building Codes Office of 
the City of Beaufort, being marked and designated as the International Residential Code, as adopted and 
amended by the South Carolina Building Codes Council, and any revisions thereof when received by the 
City of Beaufort, be and is herby adopted as the Residential Code of the City of Beaufort, South Carolina, 
for the control of building and structures as provided herein; and each and all of the regulations, 
provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said residential code are hereby referred to, adopted and 
made part hereof, as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if 
any, prescribed in section 5-1016 of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-24-02, 6-25-02; Ord. No. O-02-10, § 1, 1-26-10)

"These provisions shall be known as the Residential Code for One and Two-Family Dwellings of the 
City of Beaufort." 
(b) ?Section R108.2 Schedule of Permit Fees, of the International Residential Code for One- and Two-
Family Dwellings shall be amended to read as follows: "The fees for residential construction permits 
and other related services shall be as provided in section 5-1003(f) of the City of Beaufort Code of 
Ordinances."
