(b) ?The operator or owner may refuse service to disorderly or intoxicated persons or those individuals 
who have a history of failure to pay for services rendered. 
(Ord. No. O-12-90, 3-13-90) 


Sec. 7-4031. - Daily manifests. 
(a) ?Every operator of a public conveyance shall maintain a daily manifest for each vehicle upon which 
are recorded all trips made each day showing the time, place of origin, destination of each trip and 
the number of passengers, the amount of the fare, and all such completed manifests shall be 
returned to the owner by the operator at the conclusion of his/her tour of duty. Daily manifests shall 
be promptly recapitulated by the owner and operator on a monthly tally sheet. The forms for each 
manifest shall be furnished to the operator by the owner and shall be of a character approved by city 
council. 
(b) ?Every holder of a license pursuant to this chapter shall retain and preserve all daily operators' 
manifests in a safe place for at least the current calendar year and preceding calendar year, and 
such manifests shall be inspected periodically, from time to time, by the city manager or his designee 
or agent. Such manifests shall also be made available for inspection upon the request of any police 
officer. 
(Ord. No. O-12-90, 3-13-90) 


Sec. 7-4032. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-08-96, adopted March 12, 1996, deleted § 7-4032 concerning 
monthly tally sheets which had derived from Ord. No. O-12-90, adopted March 13, 1990. 


Sec. 7-4033. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Former § 7-4033 was deleted by Ord. No. O-18-91, adopted May 14, 1991. The 
deleted provisions pertained to air conditioning in public motor passenger vehicles and derived 
from Ord. No. O-12-90, adopted Mar. 13, 1990. 


Sec. 7-4034. - Rate meters required. 
    Each taxi operating under this chapter shall be required to have installed in the vehicle a meter for 
determining trip fares within the service area. Meters will be used for local fares within a twelve-mile 
radius of the Federal Court Building on Bay Street in downtown Beaufort, including the military bases. 
Meter or rate schedules for a single trip will include one to four (4) passengers. Rate schedules may be 
used for trips to Hilton Head and Savannah airports plus the Yemassee train station, but these schedules 
must be filed with the public service commission. The provisions of this section which pertains to rate 
meters and schedules will become effective July 1, 1992. 
(Ord. No. O-12-90, 3-13-90; Ord. No. O-18-91, 5-14-91) 


Sec. 7-4035. - Designation of stands. 
    The city council may designate stands for public motor passenger vehicles. Consideration shall be 
given to the effect upon traffic, parking and convenience to the public when establishing such stands. All 
taxi stands shall be subject to use by any licensed public passenger motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-12-90, 3-13-90) 


CHAPTER 5. - AUCTIONS AND OTHER SALES 


Sec. 7-5001. - General provisions. 
(a) ?No person shall sell or offer for sale, by auction or at auction sale, any of the articles of property or 
merchandise mentioned in section 7-5009, irrespective of how or when acquired, between the hours 
of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. Any person who shall sell or offer for sale by auction or at auction sale 
any of the articles of property or merchandise mentioned in such section shall not offer sale for sale 
or sell same unless there is attached to each of such articles a tag or label containing the information 
provided for and required in such section, which tag or label shall remain securely attached to any 
article of merchandise and be delivered to the purchaser. Any such person so selling or offering for 
sale, by auction or at auction sale, shall, before selling or offering for sale, file with clerk of the city a 
good and sufficient bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), to be approved by the city 
clerk, to the effect that such person conducting such sale will not mislead the public and to indemnify 
the public against loss in consequence of being misled or overreached. 
(b) ?For the purpose of this section, the terms "selling by auction" or "auction" shall be taken to mean the 
offering for sale of personal property to the highest bidder, or offering for sale or selling of such 
property by the method known as "down hill selling." By "down hill selling" is meant the first offering 
of an article at a higher price and then offering the same at successive lower price. 
(Code 1962, § 5-1) 


Sec. 7-5002. - Sales excepted from application. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not extend to judicial sales, sales under execution, or to bona fide 
executors' or administrators' sales nor to sales at auction where merchandise is turned over to a bona fide 
creditor or association of creditors to be sold for the benefit of such creditor or association of creditors. 
(Code 1962, § 5-2) 


Sec. 7-5003. - Sale of bankrupt, insolvent stock or fire stock. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings 
respective ascribed to them by this section: 
(1) ?Bankrupt stock; stock of an insolvent. The terms "bankrupt stock" and "stock of an insolvent" 
shall be taken to include any stock of goods, wares, merchandise, furniture, fixtures, jewelry, or 
personal property of any nature acquired from the trustee or referee in bankruptcy, a receiver or 
assignee. 
(2) ?Fire stock. The term "fire stock" shall be taken to include any goods, wares, furniture, fixtures, 
jewelry or merchandise which are or have been damaged by fire or which are or have been 
claimed to have been damaged by fire or which are to have been or which are claimed to be or 
have been sold or purchased on account of any fire. 
(Code 1962, § 5-3) 


Sec. 7-5004. - Application of chapter generally. 
    This chapter shall apply whether the person actually conducting the sale of bankrupt stock, stock of 
an insolvent or fire stock, or the "closing-out-sale," "going-out-of-business sale," "discontinuance-of-
business sale" or other like sale acquired the stock of goods involved from the trustee, referee, receiver or 
assignee or from any person, if such stock is offered to the public in the manner described in this chapter 
at any time within six (6) months from the date title passed out of the referee, receiver, trustee or 
assignee or other person and shall include any stock or goods, wares, merchandise, furniture, fixtures or 
jewelry which shall be sold or offered for sale any other way than through the usual channels of trade. 
(Code 1962, § 5-4) 


Sec. 7-5005. - License required; term of license. 
    Every person who shall take over or become the owner of or manager of any bankrupt stock of 
merchandise or of merchandise of an insolvent or fire stock of merchandise or wares which have been 
damaged or claimed to have been damaged by fire or purchased on account of fire and who shall offer 
the same or any portion of the same for sale to the public in a manner commonly known as a "bankrupt 
sale" or in the manner commonly known as an "insolvency sale" or in a manner commonly known as a 
"fire sale" or under any other designation, or shall conduct a "closing-out-sale," "going-out-of-business 
sale," "discontinuance-of-business sale" or other like sale shall, before offering such merchandise for sale 
to the public, secure a license therefor from the clerk-treasurer in accordance with the provisions of this 
chapter. No license as provided for herein shall be valid for a longer period than 60 days. 
(Code 1962, § 5-5) 


Sec. 7-5006. - License fee. 
    Every person applying for a license, as required in section 7-5005, shall pay a special license fee 
therefor in an amount equal to five percent (5%) of the invested capital paid to the assignee, receiver, 
trustee in bankruptcy or other person from whom the stock of goods in question was acquired. 
(Code 1962, § 5-6) 


Sec. 7-5007. - Filing of inventory of stock to be included in sale. 
    Before any person shall, within the city, conduct any sale pursuant to a license as required in section 
7-5005, such person shall file in the office of the clerk-treasurer an inventory thereof, duly sworn to, 
setting up the quality, quantity, kind or grade of the items thereof, to which inventory shall be attached an 
affidavit that is in all respects true and correct. In the case of an individual, such affidavit shall be made by 
him as such, and in the case of a firm, such inventory shall be made by one of the partners, and in the 
case of the corporation it shall be made by the president or general manager, secretary or treasurer. 
Such inventory and affidavit shall be kept on file as part of the public records of the city clerk. 
(Code 1962, § 5-7) 


Sec. 7-5008. - Sale of stock not included in inventory. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who has filed an inventory, as required in section 7-5007, to add to 
stock, listed in such inventory, from any source whatsoever and advertise the same as a bankrupt stock 
or as an insolvent stock or as a fire stock or to offer for sale any goods, wares, merchandise, furniture, 
fixtures, jewelry, or personal property along with same or in the same building which were not a part of 
the original bankrupt stock or insolvent stock or fire stock. 
(Code 1962, § 5-8) 


Sec. 7-5009. - Tags or labels when diamonds, watches, jewelry, oriental rugs, etc., are sold; sale of 
watches and clocks. 
    If the stock of merchandise offered for sale under a license issued under this chapter shall consist in 
whole or in part of any diamonds or any other precious or semi-precious stones or imitations thereof, 
watches, clocks, jewelry, glassware, oriental rugs, bric-a-brac, or light merchandise, the same shall not be 
offered for sale or be sold unless there is securely attached to each of such articles a tag or label upon 
which shall be plainly written or printed, in English, a true and correct statement of the kind and quality of 
the metal or material of which such article is made or composed and if of metal the percentage or 
character, or purity of such metal, and in case such articles are plated or overlaid, then such tag or label 
shall contain a true statement of the kind of material or metal covering, and when precious or 
semiprecious stones are offered for sale or sold, such written statement shall set forth the true name, 
weight, quantity, and fineness of such stones and imitations shall be described as such, and when 
watches and clocks are sold, the true name of the manufacturers shall be stated in writing and no part of 
the movement or mechanism thereof shall be substituted or contain false or misleading names or trade 
marks, neither shall secondhand or old movements be offered for sale in new cases without a true 
statement to that effect. Such tag and label shall remain securely attached to any article of merchandise 
and shall be delivered to the purchaser as a true and correct description and representation of the article 
sold and shall be deemed prima facie evidence of intent to defraud in case such written statement is not 
true and correct. 
(Code 1962, § 5-9) 


Sec. 7-5010. - Bond. 
    Every person conducting a bankrupt sale, insolvency sale or fire sale, pursuant to a license as 
required in section 7-5005, shall before commencing such sale, file with the city clerk, a good and 
sufficient bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), to be approved by the city clerk, to the 
effect that such person conducting such sale will not mislead the public by any false or untrue advertising, 
or by holding back and not offering for sale any part of the stock in question or by shipping in or bringing 
in from other sources, goods or merchandise in such manner as the public may be led to believe that 
such additional goods, and merchandise, so shipped in or brought in, were part of the original stock, and 
to the further effect that such person so conducting such sale will not, in any manner mislead, cheat, or 
defraud, or attempt to cheat, mislead, or defraud the public in the conduct of the sale. 
(Code 1962, § 5-10) 


Sec. 7-5011. - Flea market inspection. 
    Upon approval of a permit or business license for a flea market, city police officers may enter the 
premises during the hours of operation for the purpose of viewing and inspecting items offered for sale or 
trade. 


Sec. 7-5012. - Sale of unclaimed personal property recovered by city. 
(a) ?Bicycles, cameras, electronic equipment, office machines, watches, clocks, jewelry and/or any other 
items of personal property, except firearms, which have been lost, stolen, or abandoned and are 
recovered by or turned in to the city and remain unclaimed for a period of sixty (60) days, where the 
true owner cannot be found after reasonable effort, shall be subject to sale by the police department. 
(b) ?An advertisement of any such sale shall be placed in a newspaper of general circulation within the 
city at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date of such sale. 
(c) ?All proceeds from the sale of such unclaimed personal property shall be paid into the general fund 
of the city. 
(d) ?Firearms are excluded from this provision and will be disposed of in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. O-07-82, §§ 1—4, 6-15-82) 


CHAPTER 6. - PARADES, PICKET LINES, GROUP DEMONSTRATIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-27-00, adopted June 13, 2000, deleted §§ 7-6001—7-6009, and enacted 
similar provisions to read as herein set out. Former §§ 7-6001—7-6009 derived from Ord. No. O-24-92, 
adopted Oct. 27, 1992; Ord. No. O-30-93, adopted Oct. 12, 1993; and Ord. No. O-06-95, adopted April 
25, 1995. 


Sec. 7-6001. - Definitions. 
    [For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the definitions ascribed:] 
(a) ?Parade means any march, procession or motorcade consisting of persons, animals, or vehicles 
or a combination thereof upon the streets within the city that interferes with the normal flow or 
regulation of traffic upon the streets. 
(b) ?Parade or public assembly permit means a permit as required by this chapter. 
(c) ?Public assembly means any meeting, demonstration, picket line, rally or gathering of more than 
fifty (50) persons for a common purpose as a result of prior planning that interferes with the 
normal flow or regulation of pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(d) ?Sidewalk is any area or way set aside or open to the general public for purposes of pedestrian 
traffic. 
(e) ?Street is any place or way set aside or open to the general public for purposes of vehicular 
traffic, including any berm or shoulder parkway, right-of-way, or median strip thereof, set aside 
for parking or for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6002. - Permit required. 
    No person shall engage in or conduct any parade or public assembly unless a permit is issued by the 
city manager. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6003. - Exceptions. 
    This chapter shall not apply to the following: 
(a) ?Funeral processions; 
(b) ?A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions; and 
(c) ?Spontaneous events occasioned by news or affairs coming into public knowledge within three 
(3) days of such public assembly, provided that the organizer thereof gives written notice to the 
city, at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to such parade or public assembly. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6004. - Application. 
(a) ?A person seeking a parade or public assembly permit shall file an application with the city manager 
on forms provided by the city manager and the application shall be signed by the applicant. 
(b) ?An application for a permit shall be filed with the city manager at least ten (10) and not more than 
one hundred eighty (180) days before the parade or public assembly is proposed to commence. The 
city manager may waive the minimum ten (10) day filing period and accept an application filed within 
a shorter period if, after due consideration of the date, time, place, and nature of the parade or public 
assembly, the anticipated number of participants, and the city services required in connection with 
the event, the city manager determines that the waiver will not present a hazard to public safety. 
(c) ?The application for a parade or public assembly permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1) ?The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade or 
public assembly; 
(2) ?The names, addresses and telephone numbers of the headquarters of the organization for 
which the parade or public assembly is to be conducted, if any, and the authorized and 
responsible heads of the organization; 
(3) ?The requested date of the parade or public assembly; 
(4) ?The route to be traveled, including the starting point and the termination point; 
(5) ?The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which will constitute such 
parade or public assembly and the type of animals and description of the vehicles; 
(6) ?The hours when such parade or public assembly will start and terminate; 
(7) ?A statement as to whether the parade or public assembly will occupy all or only a portion of the 
width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
(8) ?The location by street of any assembly areas for such parade or public assembly; 
(9) ?The time at which units of the parade or public assembly will begin to assemble at any such 
area; 
(10) ?The intervals of space to be maintained between units of such parade or public assembly; 
(11) ?If the parade or public assembly is designed to be held by, or on behalf of any person other 
than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file a letter from that person with the city 
manager authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf; 
(12) ?The type of public assembly, including a description of activities planned during the event; 
(13) ?A description of any recording equipment, sound amplification equipment, and a physical 
description of banners, signs, or other attention-getting devices to be used in connection with 
the parade or public assembly, and the maximum decibel level of any such sound amplification 
equipment; 
(14) ?The approximate number of participants (spectators are by definition not participants); 
[(15) ?Reserved;] 
(16) ?A designation of any public facilities or equipment to be utilized. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6005. - Fees. 
(a) ?A nonrefundable fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to cover administrative costs of processing the 
permit shall be paid to the City of Beaufort by the applicant when the application is filed. 
(b) ?If the application is for the use of any city property or if any city services shall be required for the 
parade or public assembly, the applicant shall pay, prior to the issuance of a permit, the charges for 
those services in accordance with a schedule of service costs approved by the city council by 
resolution. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6006. - Standards for issuance. 
(a) ?The city manager shall issue a permit as provided for herein when, from a consideration of the 
application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1) ?The conduct of the parade or public assembly will not require the diversion of so great a 
number of city police officers to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous 
thereto as to prevent normal police protection of the city; 
(2) ?The parade or public assembly is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of 
termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route; 
(3) ?There are sufficient parking places near the site of the parade or public assembly to 
accommodate the number of vehicles reasonably expected; 
(4) ?Such parade or public assembly is not for the primary purpose of advertising any product, 
goods or event that is primarily for private profit, and the parade itself is not primarily for profit. 
The prohibition against advertising any product, goods or event shall not apply to signs 
identifying organizations or sponsors furnishing or sponsoring exhibits or structures used in the 
parade; 
(5) ?No parade or public assembly permit application for the same time and location is already 
granted or has been received and will be granted; 
(6) ?No parade or public assembly permit application for the same time but different location is 
already granted or has been received and will be granted, and the police resources required for 
that prior parade or public assembly are so great that in combination with the subsequent 
proposed application, the resulting deployment of police services would have an immediate and 
adverse effect upon the welfare and safety of persons and property; and 
(b) ?No permit shall be granted that allows for the erection or placement of any structure, whether 
permanent or temporary, on a city street, sidewalk, or right-of-way unless advance approval for the 
erection or placement of the structure is obtained from the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6007. - Nondiscrimination. 
    The city manager shall uniformly consider each application upon its merits and shall not discriminate 
in granting or denying permits under this chapter based upon political, religious, ethnic, race, disability, 
sexual orientation or gender related pounds. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6008. - Notice of denial of application. 
    The city manager shall act promptly upon a timely filed application for a parade or public assembly 
permit but in no event shall grant or deny a permit less than four (4) days prior to the event. If the city 
manager disapproves the application, he shall notify the applicant either by personal delivery or certified 
mail at least four (4) days prior to the event of his action and state the reasons for denial. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6009. - Alternative permit. 
(a) ?The city manager, in denying an application for a parade or public assembly permit, may authorize 
the conduct of the parade or public assembly at a date, time, location, or route different from that 
named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within five (5) days 
after notice of the action of the city manager, file a written notice of acceptance with the city 
manager. 
(b) ?An alternate parade or public assembly permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have 
the effect of, a parade or public assembly permit issued under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6010. - Appeal procedure. 
(a) ?Any applicant shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade or public assembly permit to the 
city council. The denied applicant shall make the appeal within five (5) days after receipt of the denial 
by filing a written notice with the city manager and a copy of the notice with the city clerk. The city 
council shall promptly act upon the appeal at the next scheduled meeting following receipt of the 
notice of appeal. 
(b) ?In the event that the city council rejects an applicant's appeal, the applicant may file an immediate 
request for prompt judicial review with a court of competent jurisdiction. In the event of any such 
review, the city shall file its response to the complaint or appeal motion within ten (10) days of 
service of same, and will join with the applicant in an application to the court for an expedited hearing 
and decision of the appeal at the next available term of court. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6011. - Notice to city and other officials. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a parade or public assembly permit, the city manager shall send a 
copy thereof to the following: 
(a) ?The mayor and members of city council; 
(b) ?The chief of police; 
(c) ?The city attorney; 
(d) ?The fire chief; 
(e) ?The director of the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6012. - Contents of permit. 
    Each parade or public assembly permit shall state the following information: 
(a) ?Starting and approximate ending time; 
(b) ?Maximum interval of space to be maintained between parade units; 
(c) ?The portions of the streets that may be occupied by the parade or public assembly; 
(d) ?The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; and 
(e) ?Such other information as the city manager shall find necessary to the enforcement of this 
chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6013. - Duties of permittee. 
(a) ?A permittee hereunder shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable 
laws and ordinances. 
(b) ?The parade or public assembly chairman or other person heading such activity shall carry the 
parade or public assembly permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade or public 
assembly. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6014. - Prohibitions. 
    The following prohibitions shall apply to all parades and public assemblies: 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to stage, present, or conduct any parade or public assembly 
without first having obtained a permit as herein provided; 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in a parade or public assembly for which the 
person knows a permit has not been granted; 
(c) ?It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of, or responsible for the conduct of, a duly 
licensed parade or public assembly to knowingly fail to comply with any condition of the permit; 
(d) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any parade or public assembly activity that 
would constitute a substantial hazard to the public safety or that would materially interfere with 
or endanger the public peace or rights of residents to the quiet and peaceful enjoyment of their 
property; 
(e) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to ride, drive, or cause to be ridden or driven any animal or 
any animal-drawn vehicle upon any public street, unless specifically authorized by the permit. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6015. - Public conduct during parades or public assemblies. 
(a) ?No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or public 
assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade or public assembly. 
(b) ?Unless otherwise directed by a police officer directing traffic, no driver of a vehicle shall drive 
between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade or public assembly when such vehicles or 
persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade or public assembly. 
(c) ?The chief of police, or his designee, shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit 
or restrict the parking of vehicles along a street constituting a part of the route of a parade or public 
assembly. The chief of police shall post signs to that effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to 
park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6016. - Revocation of permit. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to revoke a parade or public assembly permit instantly 
upon violation of the conditions or standards for issuance as set forth in this chapter or when a public 
emergency arises where the police resources required for that emergency are so great that deployment 
of police services for the parade or public assembly would have an immediate and adverse effect upon 
the welfare and safety, of persons or property. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6017. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating the provisions of any section of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished 
by fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment of not more than thirty (30) days, or 
both. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


Sec. 7-6018. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or 
unconstitutional by the decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the 
validity of the remaining portions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-27-00, 6-13-2000) 


CHAPTER 7. - INTOXICATING BEVERAGES 


Sec. 7-7001. - Appearing drunk on streets. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to appear upon any of the streets or alleys of the city who is 
under the influence of intoxicating liquors, narcotic drugs, barbiturates, paraldehydes or drugs, herbs 
or any other substances of like character, whether synthetic or natural. 
(b) ?It shall also be unlawful for any person, while in such condition, to appear, or be in or upon the 
grounds of any church, school, library, museum, theater, public auditorium, bus station or any other 
place or thing frequented or used generally by the public. It shall likewise be unlawful for a person, 
while in such condition, to enter or be in any dwelling or the business establishment of another 
except at the special invitation of the person lawfully in charge or control of such dwelling or business 
establishment. 


Sec. 7-7002. - Public drinking. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to consume or possess in an open container any intoxicating 
liquors, including beer, ale, porter, wine or other similar malt or fermented beverage upon any public 
street, alley, park, parking lot, public boat landing, playground or upon any unlicensed premises 
within the city without special permission of city council. This section does not apply to the Henry C. 
Chambers Park. These regulations are covered in sections 7-7002(b) and (c). 
(b) ?It shall also be unlawful for any person to possess, sell or consume alcoholic beverages mentioned 
in the above paragraph in the Henry C. Chambers Park without prior approval of the city manager. 
(c) ?Consumption of alcoholic beverages at private functions in the Henry C. Chambers Park may be 
approved by the city manager. Sale, payment or acceptance of any type contribution for alcoholic 
beverages at private functions is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. O-16-91, 4-23-91; Ord. No. O-16-94, Ord. No. 10-25-94; Ord. No. O-11-98, 2-10-98; 
Ord. No. O-44-00, § 1, 10-24-00) 
Cross reference— Parks, § 3-2001 et seq. 


Sec. 7-7003. - Drinking liquors in public conveyance. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to drink intoxicating liquors, including beer, ale, porter, wine or 
other similar malt or fermented beverage in any public conveyance within the city. 
(b) ?This section shall not apply to any railroad dining or club car or to any aircraft of a commercial airline 
transporting passengers for hire. 


Sec. 7-7004. - Possession of open containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any open container containing beer, ale, 
porter, wine or other similar malt or fermented beverage in a vehicle on any public street, parking lot, alley 
or way within this city. 


Sec. 7-7005. - Drinking at athletic events prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the drinking of any beer, ale, wine or intoxicating 
liquors upon any premises upon which a public athletic contest is being conducted. 


Sec. 7-7006. - Sale or consumption in parks on Sunday. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or group to possess, consume or sell intoxicating beverages on 
Sundays in any public park within the city. 
(Ord. No. O-16-91, 4-23-91) 
Cross reference— Parks, § 3-2001 et seq. 
? 


CHAPTER 8. - PRECIOUS METALS DEALERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-07-81, adopted Feb. 24, 1981, added Ch. 5 to Part 2; for purposes of 
classification, the editor has redesignated this material as Ch. 8 of Pt. 7. 


Sec. 7-8001. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, certain words and phrases shall be construed herein as set forth in 
this section, unless it is apparent from the context that a different meaning is intended: 
    Dealer: Any person who holds himself out to the public as a purchaser of precious metals, or who in 
the course of operation of a licensed business engages in the purchase of silver, gold or platinum. 
    Precious metals: Any article made, in whole or in part, of gold, silver or platinum, which article or part 
thereof has been used or sold, or is being held or processed by a retailer. The term "precious metal" shall 
not include any coin(s) having a current retail value of less than forty-nine dollars ($49.00), but shall 
include all other coins. 
    Wholesale precious metals: Articles made in whole or in part of silver, gold or platinum that have not 
been previously used, nor traded or sold by a retailer, and that are being purchased by a dealer from a 
manufacturer or from a wholesaler or distributor of newly manufactured precious metals or items thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-07-81, 2-24-81) 


Sec. 7-8002. - License and place of operating. 
    No dealer as defined herein shall operate in the city unless he first obtains a permit from the license 
inspector to engage in the business of purchasing precious metals, and operates only from a permanent 
shop or place of business. No dealer shall operate upon public property nor from a vehicle, flea market, 
hotel room or similar temporary location. 
(Ord. No. O-07-81, 2-24-81; Ord. No. O-33-93, 11-23-93) 


Sec. 7-8003. - Additional requirements for permit. 
(a) ?The form of the permit to engage in the business of purchasing precious metals shall be prescribed 
by the license inspector; and all applicants for a city precious metal permit under this chapter, 
whether a person, firm or corporation, shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant, if 
an individual(s), by all the partners if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation, with the 
license inspector showing: 
(1) ?The names of the persons managing or supervising the applicant's business in the locality; the 
addresses of such persons; the social security number of such persons; the capacity in which 
such persons will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent, or otherwise); the name and address 
of the persons, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any, and 
if the corporation, the state of incorporation. 
(2) ?The places in the state where it is proposed to carry out the applicant's business and the 
places where the applicant has carried on the business of purchasing precious metals within 
one year preceding the date of such application. 
(3) ?A statement of the nature, character and quality of the precious metals to be purchased in the 
business. 
(4) ?Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of the persons managing or 
supervising the applicant's business or the method of plan of doing such business as the 
license inspector may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of public 
good. 
(b) ?Upon receipt of such application for a permit, the license inspector shall cause an investigation of 
such person's business responsibility and/or moral character to be made as he deems necessary for 
the protection of the public good. If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business 
reputation are found to be satisfactory, the permit shall be issued. The permit shall be denied or 
issued within thirty (30) days from the date of application. 
(c) ?The permit issued under this chapter shall be valid for a period of one year from the date issued and 
shall be posted conspicuously in the place(s) of business named therein. 
(d) ?If the dealer intends to operate in more than one location within the city, a separate permit shall be 
obtained from the license inspector for each place of business; provided, however, only one annual 
fee shall be collected. 
(e) ?The permit(s) under this chapter shall be in addition to and not in lieu of other business licenses. 
(f) ?A permit may be denied or revoked at any time if the license inspector discovers that the information 
on the application is inaccurate or false or the dealer or application does not comply with the 
requirements of this chapter or otherwise violates federal, state or local law. 
(Ord. No. O-07-81, 2-24-81; Ord. No. O-33-93, 11-23-93) 


Sec. 7-8004. - Report to police, positive identification of sellers, photographs of purchases, retention of 
records. 
(a) ?Every dealer shall mail or deliver daily reports on forms supplied by the police department to the 
chief of police of the city, within twenty-four (24) hours from the time of purchase, giving the name 
and address of the seller, the price paid for each item, the date of purchase, a description of each 
article purchased, the manufacturer (where known), any identifying marks on each article, the seller's 
social security number and the seller's driver's license number or the number on any governmental 
identification card bearing a photograph of the seller; provided however, that if the seller cannot 
furnish a driver's license or other identification bearing his photograph, the dealer with the consent of 
the seller shall photograph such seller. If the seller shall refuse to allow the dealer to take his 
photograph, then the dealer shall not purchase any precious metals from that seller. The photograph 
shall include the head, face and shoulders of the seller and such photographs shall be suitable for 
ready identification of the seller and the purchased items. 
(b) ?The dealer shall also record descriptions of the seller and the property purchased as required in this 
section in a bound book with consecutively numbered pages which shall be retained for three (3) 
years. 
(c) ?The dealer in such goods shall also take a photograph of each group of purchased precious metals 
using an instant photograph process when the total value of the purchase exceeds fifty dollars 
($50.00), which photographs shall be forwarded to the chief of police of the city with the daily report 
required in this section. On the back of each photograph the dealer shall record the date of the 
purchase and the name and address of the seller and the dealer shall sign or initial it. All such 
photographs shall be forwarded to the chief of police attached to the daily report of the particular 
purchase for which it was taken. 
(d) ?Any records required to be kept or maintained by this section shall at all times be open to the 
inspection of the chief of police or an officer duly authorized by him to inspect the same. 
(e) ?The police department shall not reveal a seller's identity supplied under this section, except to other 
law enforcement agencies and prosecuting officials, or pursuant to the valid order of a court, or in the 
course of any criminal prosecution. 
(Ord. No. O-07-81, 2-24-81) 


Sec. 7-8005. - Purchase from minors prohibited. 
    No dealer shall purchase precious metal(s) from a person under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. O-07-81, 2-24-81) 


Sec. 7-8006. - Goods to be held for ten days before resale. 
    All precious metals purchased by a dealer must be held in the city in the possession of the dealer, 
before being resold, melted or altered in any manner, for a period of ten (10) days. 
(Ord. No. O-07-81, 2-24-81; Ord. No. O-33-93, 11-23-93) 


Sec. 7-8007. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to a transaction between dealers of precious metals, 
where the selling dealer is licensed and has complied with the terms of this chapter, including the ten-day 
holding period. 
(Ord. No. O-07-81, 2-24-81) 


Sec. 7-8008. - Penalties. 
    Any dealer or other person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a 
misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or 
imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
    Any dealer or other person so convicted shall be ineligible for a permit to conduct business in 
precious metals in the city for a period of two (2) years from the date of conviction. 
(Ord. No. O-07-81, 2-24-81; Ord. No. O-30-93, 10-12-93) 


CHAPTER 9. - SIDEWALK VENDING[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, § 3-1001 et seq. 


Sec. 7-9001. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Cart means any portable vending device, pushcart or any other wheeled vehicle or device which is 
moved without assistance of a motor and which is not required to be licensed and registered by the South 
Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles, used for the displaying, storing or transporting of articles offered 
for sale by a vendor and which does not exceed four (4) feet in width, six (6) feet in length and five (5) 
feet in height, excluding canopy or cover. 
    Vending district means the space or area specifically designated for vending by cart or carts. 
    Vendor means any person engaged in the selling or offering for sale of food, beverages, or 
merchandise on the public streets or sidewalks within the city, from a cart. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90) 


Sec. 7-9002. - Permitted merchandise. 
    Permitted merchandise at vending carts permitted by this chapter shall be limited to hot dogs, 
sausages, bagels, pastries, candy, prepacked sandwiches, fresh fruit, fruit cups, chips, biscuits, popcorn, 
nuts, pretzels, ice products, ice cream, milk products, frozen yogurt, hot and cold beverages containing 
no alcohol, flowers, and items related to permitted merchandise. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90; Ord. No. O-19-91, 5-28-91; Ord. No. O-08-10, § 1, 4-13-10) 


Sec. 7-9003. - License—Required. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful to sell, or offer for sale, any food, beverage or merchandise on any street or 
sidewalk or public park within the city from a cart without first obtaining a city business license 
therefor. 
(b) ?A city business license for not more than one year may be granted for the operation of one cart at 
location specified by resolution of city council. 
(c) ?A permit by the South Carolina Health Department that the cart or carts complies with applicable 
health standards. 
(d) ?An annual safety inspection, with certificate, for each cart by city codes enforcement and/or fire 
marshal. 
(e) ?An annual business license fee for each location shall be paid in advance. 
(f) ?The business license may not be transferred in any manner. 
(g) ?The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to festivals, community projects or public events which 
occur on a periodic basis and which are specifically approved by city council. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90) 


Sec. 7-9004. - Same—Applications. 
    The application for a vendor's city business license shall include the following information: 
(1) ?The name, home and business address of the applicant, and the name and address of the 
owner, if other than the applicant, of the cart to be used in the operation of the vending 
business. 
(2) ?A law enforcement inquiry form must be completed by each employee or applicant involved in 
sales from a vending cart. 
(3) ?A description of the type of food, beverage or merchandise to be sold. 
(4) ?A list of the proposed vending districts or locations of the vending carts for which the license is 
sought. 
(5) ?A description and photograph or drawing of the cart or carts proposed to be used. 
(6) ?The location and description of off-street cart storage facilities. 
(7) ?The method and routes for transporting carts to and from sidewalk locations and storage 
facilities. 
(8) ?The names, addresses and percentage of stock owned by shareholders in a corporate 
applicant, and the percentage interest of each partner in a partnership applicant. 
(9) ?Such other information as the applicant may choose or as may be requested by city council to 
demonstrate that applicant has the financial ability to perform the conditions of the license. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90) 


Sec. 7-9005. - Same—Issuance. 
(a) ?The business license required by section 7-9003 shall be issued by the business license inspector 
in accordance with applicable regulations. Any vendor business license issued pursuant to this 
chapter shall be subject to modification by ordinance at any time deemed necessary by council for 
the protection of public interests. Any vendor business license shall be granted as a privilege and not 
as a matter of right. Vending at any location may be temporarily suspended or relocated by the city 
manager upon reasonable notice when private or public construction or activities of the city make it 
unsafe or impractical to allow vending. 
(b) ?In determining the acceptability of an application, council may consider any factors presented in the 
application, at a public hearing or in any staff report or investigation of matters related to the past 
record and ability of the applicant to perform conditions of this chapter and the licensing agreement 
in a manner which serves the public interests. The burden for showing public convenience and 
necessity, when requested, shall rest with the applicant. The total number of vending districts shall 
be determined, from time to time, by resolution of council. 
(c) ?Not later than thirty (30) days after the filing of a completed application for a vendor's business 
license, the applicant shall be notified of a decision on the issuance or denial of the license. 
(d) ?It will be presumed that the owner of a food service business selling the same merchandise 
approved for a location within fifty (50) feet of the principal public entrance to the food services 
business area can best serve the public convenience and interests. In the event that two (2) or more 
equally acceptable applications for the same location or locations are received, the earliest 
application, if approved, shall be awarded the business license. If the business license is denied 
pursuant to section 7-9011, the applicant shall be provided with a statement of the reasons therefor 
entered in writing upon the application. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90) 


Sec. 7-9006. - Inspection and insurance. 
(a) ?A certificate of inspection or compliance as required by applicable health regulations and evidence 
of compliance with the fire code shall be filed with the finance director before any sales are made 
from carts. 
(b) ?Annual proof of an insurance policy, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the 
state, protecting the owner and the city from all claims for damages to property and bodily injury, 
including death, which may arise from operations under or in connection with the owner shall be filed 
with the finance director prior to use of the business license. Such policy shall be a general liability 
policy naming the vendor as insured in an amount not less than five hundred thousand dollars 
($500,000.00) per occurrence and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) aggregate combined single 
limit for bodily injury, personal injury and property damage. The policy shall specifically provide that 
the insurer shall provide written notice to the city at least thirty (30) days prior to cancellation, 
termination or modification of the coverage provided to the city. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90) 


Sec. 7-9007. - Location regulations. 
    No cart location in a vending district shall be: 
(1) ?Within fifty (50) feet of the principal public entrance to any food service business area not 
owned by the vendor which sells merchandise approved for sale by a vendor. 
(2) ?At any location which does not provide a clear passageway for pedestrians of at least four (4) 
feet in width. 
(3) ?Within ten (10) feet of an entranceway to any building. 
(4) ?Within fifty (50) feet of any driveway entrance to a police or fire station, or within twenty-five 
(25) feet of any other driveway. 
(5) ?At any location where it would obstruct pedestrian traffic at crosswalks or sight clearance at 
intersections. 
(6) ?Within twenty-five (25) feet of any four-way street intersection. 
(7) ?There shall be three (3) locations designated for placement of sidewalk vending carts in the 
vending district: 
a. ?Downtown Bay Street—Entrance to Waterfront Park at Bay and West Streets (west side). 
b. ?Downtown Bay Street—Entrance to Waterfront Park at Bay and West Streets (east side) 
for flowers only. 
c. ?Waterfront Park—Adjacent to the pavilion, on the water side, on the sidewalk. 
(8) ?Vending carts may be required to relocate during specific festivals and events to another 
location in the park upon notice of the park superintendent. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90; Ord. No. O-25-08, 9-9-08) 


Sec. 7-9008. - Prohibited conduct. 
    No vendor shall: 
(1) ?Vend on any street or sidewalk where vending is otherwise prohibited. 
(2) ?Vend between 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(3) ?Leave any cart unattended. 
(4) ?Store, park, or leave any cart overnight on any street or sidewalk. 
(5) ?Sell food or beverages for immediate consumption unless there is a litter receptacle which is 
available for patrons' use. 
(6) ?Leave any location without first picking up, removing and disposing of all trash or refuse 
remaining from sales made by the vendor. 
(7) ?Allow any items relating to the operation of the vending business to be placed anywhere other 
than in, on or under the cart. 
(8) ?Set up, maintain or permit the use of any table, crate, carton, rack, or any other device to 
increase the selling or display capacity of his cart. 
(9) ?Solicit or conduct business with persons in motor vehicles. 
(10) ?Sell anything other than that for which a franchise and license to vend have been issued. 
(11) ?Sell or vend anything without applicable safety and health permits. 
(12) ?Locate any stock or merchandise or store any cart within a residential zone (R) of the city 
zoning ordinance. 
(13) ?Sound or permit the sounding of any device which produces a loud and raucous noise, or use 
or operate any loud speaker, public address system, radio, sound amplifier or similar device to 
attract the attention of the public. 
(14) ?Vend without the insurance coverage specified in section 7-9006. 
(15) ?Allow the stand or any other item relating to the operation of the vending business to lean 
against or hang from any building or other structure lawfully placed on public property, without 
the owner's permission. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90) 
Cross reference— Noise, § 9-1008. 


Sec. 7-9009. - Advertising. 
    No advertising shall be permitted on any cart except to identify the name of the product or the name 
of the vendor, and the posting of prices. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90) 


Sec. 7-9010. - Renewal of license. 
    All business licenses are valid for the period of the license period unless revoked or suspended prior 
to expiration. An application to renew a business license shall be made. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90) 


Sec. 7-9011. - Denial, suspension and revocation. 
    Any franchise may be denied, suspended or revoked by council for any of the following reasons: 
(1) ?Fraud or misrepresentation contained in the application for a franchise. 
(2) ?Fraud or misrepresentation made in the course of carrying on the business of vending. 
(3) ?Conduct of the licensed business in such manner as to create a public nuisance, or constitute a 
danger to the public health, safety, welfare or morals. 
(4) ?Conduct which is contrary to the provisions of this chapter or the license. 
(5) ?Failure to use the license fully in accordance with its terms within ninety (90) days after notice 
of the grant of license, or within fifteen (15) days after notice of non-use, during the term of the 
license. 
(6) ?Failure to qualify for a business license or determination that any condition in sections 7-1015 
or 7-1016 exists. 
(7) ?A determination that the applicant is not able or qualified by reason of background, medical 
limitations, financial condition, or conditions related to the vending business to render 
acceptable service to the public pursuant to this chapter. 
(8) ?A determination that a more qualified applicant for the same location or locations will accept a 
license. 
(9) ?A determination that no license should be granted to any applicant and that a location or 
locations should be removed from the vending district approved list. 
(10) ?False application unlawful in accordance with section 7-1007. 
(11) ?If after four (4) weeks of receiving a business license and a permit by the South Carolina 
Health Department to operate the cart in the Waterfront Park, the site is not being used by the 
licensee and there has been no notification of the delay, the licensee forfeits use of the site. 
(Ord. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90; Ord. No. O-25-08, 9-9-08) 


Sec. 7-9012. - Location designation. 
    Unless otherwise allowed by city ordinance, there are two locations in the City where sidewalk 
vending is permitted: in the Waterfront Park, at the east end of the promenade, just south of the restroom 
building; and in the Waterfront Park, at the end of Charles Street Extension, just west of the 
Contemplative Garden. 
(Res. No. O-09-90, 5-8-90; Ord. No. O-08-10, § 2, 4-13-10) 


CHAPTER 10. - SIDEWALK CAFES 


Sec. 7-10001. - General. 
    Sidewalk cafes may be allowed by permit on public sidewalks according to the conditions set out in 
this article. In order to receive a permit for a sidewalk cafe on a public right-of-way, the applicant must 
demonstrate that the provisions of this article will be met. Documentation demonstrating that the 
provisions of this article will be complied with must accompany the application in order to receive a permit. 
A sidewalk cafe permit will not be issued to a permittee until after the zoning administrator and the fire 
marshall have conducted a site inspection of the proposed sidewalk cafe and all sidewalk cafe elements 
placed therein to ensure that the sidewalk cafe and all sidewalk cafe elements are in compliance with the 
approved permit and that the permittee is in compliance with all other requirements of the permit. A 
sidewalk cafe permit is valid from the date of issuance for one year. This article does not permit sidewalk 
cafes in the Henry C. Chambers Waterfront Park. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10002. - Location. 
(a) ?A sidewalk cafe shall only be permitted on a sidewalk with a minimum of ten (10) feet from the 
property line to face of curb. The area designated for the sidewalk cafe shall be considered an 
extension of the business; therefore, the location of the sidewalk cafe must be directly in front of the 
business. 
(b) ?The sidewalk cafe area must be separated from the sidewalk by barriers approved by the zoning 
administrator and the city's technical review committee as a part of the sidewalk cafe permitting 
process. All sidewalk cafes must have an opening for ingress and egress at all times. 
(c) ?A sidewalk cafe is required to maintain a clear pedestrian path of five (5) feet minimum at all times. 
This area shall be free of any obstructions such as trees, parking meters, utility poles and the like in 
order to allow adequate pedestrian movement. 
(d) ?Sidewalk cafes shall not interfere with any utilities or other facilities such as telephone poles, fire 
hydrants, signs, parking meters, mailboxes, or benches located on the sidewalk or public right-of-
way. 
(e) ?Where the city has installed a permanent structure such as a parking meter, planter, light pole or 
other device, the permittee of the sidewalk cafe shall make accommodation for the required 
clearance for pedestrian passage. Permittees of sidewalk cafes shall be mindful of the rights of 
pedestrians traveling past their sidewalk cafe at all times during the operation of the sidewalk cafe. 
Complaints regarding sidewalk cafes will be investigated by the city and violations of the ordinance 
or the rules and regulations promulgated will result in citations being issued to the permittee and/or 
revocation of permittee's sidewalk cafe permit. 
(f) ?The sidewalk cafe may not impinge on any required clear distances for maneuvering around 
entrances or exits. The outdoor dining area shall be accessible to disabled patrons and employees, 
and buildings adjacent to these areas shall maintain building egress as defined by the current 
building code. 
(g) ?When a sidewalk cafe is located at a street corner, vision clearance requirements must be 
maintained. When a sidewalk cafe is adjacent to an alley or driveway, vision clearance requirement 
may also be applied. These requirements may be modified at the discretion of the zoning 
administrator in locations where unusual circumstances exist and where public safety could be 
jeopardized. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10003. - Hours of operation. 
    Sidewalk cafes shall not operate earlier than 7:00 a.m. nor later than 1:00 a.m. unless the hours of 
the establishment are more restricted by operation of law or otherwise, in which case, the establishment's 
more restrictive hours shall control. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10004. - Compliance with food establishment regulations. 
(a) ?All sidewalk cafe employees shall be subject to and comply with all applicable requirements and 
standards for a retail food establishment. 
(b) ?Patrons must wear shoes and shirts at all times. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10005. - Maintenance. 
    All areas within and surrounding the sidewalk cafe must be maintained in a clean, neat and sanitary 
condition and shall be policed routinely by permittee to ensure removal of all wrappings, litter, debris and 
food therefrom. Daily sanitary cleaning of the sidewalk cafe is required. Sidewalks within and adjacent to 
the sidewalk cafe must be washed down and cleaned on a daily basis. The permittee shall not wash 
garbage cans or any other container, or other personal property of any nature on the sidewalks. All 
cleaning must be performed in accordance with applicable federal and state regulations. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10006. - Amplified music. 
    Sidewalk cafes shall be prohibited from playing amplified music or other amplified sound whether live 
or recorded. No speakers, microphones, televisions or other audio or video devices shall be permitted at 
a sidewalk cafe. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10007. - Storage of sidewalk cafe elements. 
    All tables, chairs, plants, planters, and any other items of the sidewalk cafe, hereinafter defined as 
sidewalk cafe elements, shall be approved as part of the permit approval process. Sidewalk cafe 
elements shall be promptly stacked/set aside immediately after the sidewalk cafe discontinues its daily 
operation, and must be removed immediately after the permittee discontinues its daily operations. 
Stacking or storing of chairs, tables, heaters or any other sidewalk cafe element in the public right-of-way 
at any other time is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10008. - Vending machines, carts prohibited. 
    No vending machines, carts, or objects for the sale of goods shall be permitted in a sidewalk cafe. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10009. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    Notwithstanding other provisions in the Code of Ordinances of the City of Beaufort, South Carolina, 
or the State of South Carolina, consumption of beer and wine purchased at the permittee's establishment 
is permitted within the area designed for sidewalk dining. No alcoholic beverages may be stored or mixed 
in the sidewalk cafe area. Equipment necessary for the dispensing of any other items should be reported 
as part of the operation of the sidewalk cafe and is subject to review. The business must provide 
supervision of the sidewalk cafe area to ensure the conduct of patrons and operations of the area are in 
compliance with this ordinance at all times. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10010. - Smoking. 
    Notwithstanding other provisions in the Code of Ordinances of the City of Beaufort, South Carolina, 
smoking is permitted within the area designated for sidewalk dining, if authorized by the permittee. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10011. - Furniture, objects, structures and decor. 
(a) ?Tables, chairs, umbrellas, awnings, barriers and any other object associated with a sidewalk cafe 
("sidewalk cafe elements") shall be of quality design, materials and workmanship both to ensure the 
safety and convenience of users and to enhance the visual and aesthetic quality of the urban 
environment. All sidewalk cafe elements shall be reviewed by the zoning administrator and the city's 
technical review committee as a part of the sidewalk cafe permitting process. In reviewing sidewalk 
cafe elements, the technical review committee shall consider their character and appropriateness of 
design including but not limited to scale, texture, materials, color and the relation of the sidewalk cafe 
elements to the establishments, to features of structures in the immediate surroundings to the 
streetscape and adjacent neighborhood(s), if applicable. 
(b) ?Tables and chairs for sidewalk dining shall be placed in the area designated for sidewalk dining 
only. Appropriate density of tables and chairs is to be reviewed by the zoning administrator and 
technical review committee, and may be affected by specific conditions of the location. Table sizes 
should be kept to a minimum so as to not cause crowding, a disturbance or a nuisance. 
(c) ?Permanent structures in sidewalk cafes are not permitted. All furniture, umbrellas or other sidewalk 
cafe elements shall not be attached permanently to the sidewalk or public right-of-way. The 
permittee shall be responsible for the restoration of the sidewalk or public right-of-way if any damage 
is caused as a result of the issuance of the sidewalk cafe permit. 
(d) ?Paper and plastic products for the consumption of food or beverages are not permitted at sidewalk 
cafes. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10012. - Overhead structures. 
(a) ?Umbrellas and any type of temporary overhead structure may be utilized if approved by the zoning 
administrator upon a favorable recommendation by the technical review committee as a part of the 
sidewalk cafe permitting process. The use of overhead structures over the outdoor dining areas and 
removable umbrellas may be permitted provided they do not interfere with street trees. No portion of 
the umbrella shall be less than seven (7) feet above the sidewalk. Umbrellas and any type of 
overhead structure shall be designed to be secure during windy conditions and shall be weather 
resistant. 
(b) ?Awnings, either permanent or temporary, may be utilized if approved by the zoning administrator 
upon a favorable recommendation by the technical review committee and the historic district review 
board, if applicable, as a part of the sidewalk cafe permitting process. Awnings shall have no support 
posts located within the public right-of-way, and no portion of an awning shall be less than eight (8) 
feet above the sidewalk. A building permit must be obtained prior to the installation of an awning and 
is subject to all applicable sections of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Beaufort, South Carolina. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10013. - Signage. 
    Signs advertising sale of goods or services at a sidewalk cafe shall be prohibited. This prohibition 
includes, but is not limited to, sandwich boards, banners, writing or signs as part of the furniture or on 
umbrellas, pamphlets, podiums, or any other sidewalk cafe element containing a sign or advertisement. 
Menus shall be restricted to a maximum size not to exceed nine (9) inches wide and twelve (12) inches 
long and shall be secured to tabletops or designed in order to prevent debris. A sign posted in a visible 
location is required at every sidewalk cafe, which states, "It is unlawful to consume alcoholic beverages 
not purchased at permittee's establishment or its sidewalk cafe or to remove alcoholic beverages from the 
sidewalk cafe." 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10014. - Lighting. 
    Lighting for sidewalk cafes may be utilized if approved by the zoning administrator upon a favorable 
recommendation by the technical review committee as a part of the sidewalk cafe permitting process. Any 
such lighting shall compliment the existing building and sidewalk cafe design and shall not cause a glare 
to passing pedestrians or vehicles. Electrical wires shall not be permitted to access the sidewalk cafe 
area. Possible lighting sources include tabletop candles or low wattage battery-operated fixtures. 
Additional lighting may be attached to the permittee's adjacent establishment provided permittee obtains 
all necessary approvals for such lighting from the city and the historic district review board, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10015. - Outdoor heaters. 
    Outdoor heaters may be utilized upon the approval of the zoning administrator upon a favorable 
recommendation by the technical review committee as a part of the sidewalk cafe permitting process. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10016. - Service. 
(a) ?All services provided to patrons of a sidewalk cafe and all patron activity (i.e., sitting dining, waiting, 
etc.) shall occur within the designated sidewalk cafe area, and shall not impinge on the required 
clear distance for pedestrian passage at any time. 
(b) ?The business must provide supervision of the sidewalk cafe area to ensure the conduct of patrons 
and operations of the area are in compliance with this chapter at all times. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10017. - Fees. 
    If a permit is issued, permittee shall be required to pay an annual fee of three hundred dollars 
($300.00) to the City of Beaufort. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10018. - Insurance required. 
    Each permittee of a sidewalk cafe permit shall furnish a certificate of insurance evidencing 
commercial general liability insurance with limits of not less than six hundred thousand dollars 
($600,000.00) per occurrence, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) in the aggregate combined single limit, 
for bodily injury, personal injury and property damage liability with the City of Beaufort as an additional 
named insured. The insurance shall provide for thirty (30) days prior written notice to be given to the City 
of Beaufort if coverage is substantially changed, canceled or nonrenewed. 
    The City of Beaufort shall be named as an additional insured on a primary, noncontributory basis for 
any liability arising directly or indirectly from the operation of a sidewalk cafe; and the permittee shall 
indemnify, defend and hold the city harmless from any loss that results directly or indirectly from the 
permit issuance or the operation of the sidewalk cafe. 
    In addition, if alcoholic beverages will be served at the sidewalk cafe, the permittee shall provide 
proof of liquor liability insurance for the sidewalk cafe, with limits of not less than one million dollars 
($1,000,000.00) in such type as shall be acceptable to the city. 
    Each permittee shall maintain the insurance coverage required under this section during the permit 
period. The certificate(s) of insurance shall be presented to the zoning administrator prior to the issuance 
of a permit under this section. Failure of the permittee to maintain the insurance required by this section 
shall result in the revocation of the sidewalk cafe permit. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10019. - Enforcement. 
    The issuance of a sidewalk cafe permit is a privilege granted by the City of Beaufort. The City of 
Beaufort requires compliance with all rules and regulations as well as to have respect for the community 
in which the cafe is located. The zoning administrator, city codes compliance officer, or city building 
inspectors will inspect all sidewalk cafes after permits have been issued and the cafe is in operation. The 
zoning administrator and codes compliance officers will monitor the operation of sidewalk cafes and are 
empowered to issue citations for ordinance or rule or regulation violations. The zoning administrator has 
the authority to suspend or revoke a sidewalk cafe permit based on repeated violations of these rules and 
regulations. Any violations of the provisions of these rules and regulations, or any deviation from 
approved plans or willful omissions of the application will result in citations being issued to the operator 
and/or revocation of permittee's sidewalk cafe permit. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


Sec. 7-10020. - Penalties for violation. 
    Any permittee or his or her employees, agents or contractors who violate or resist enforcement of 
any provision of the sidewalk cafe ordinance and/or these rules and regulations may be subject to 
immediate permit revocation by the city and/or shall be subject to a fine of not less than that set forth in 
section 1-3048 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Beaufort, South Carolina, provided that each day 
that such violation continues shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. These fines shall be in 
addition to any expenses incurred for restoration or repair of the public right-of-way, which shall be the 
responsibility of the permittee. 
(Ord. No. O-32-08, 11-25-08) 


CHAPTER 11. - TOURISM MANAGEMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-13-04, adopted June 8, 2004, amended Ch. 11 by consolidating its provisions 
with Ch. 10, Animal-Drawn Vehicles for Hire, to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 11 was formerly 
comprised of §§ 7-11001—7-11021 and 7-11022—7-11030, and derived from Ord. No. O-08-94, adopted 
June 14, 1994; Ord. No. O-11-96, adopted March 26, 1996; Ord. No. O-64-99, adopted Dec. 14, 1999; 
Ord. No. O-04-01, adopted Jan. 23, 2001; and Ord. No. O-27-02, adopted July 9, 2002. 


Sec. 7-11001. - Applicability. 
    This chapter shall apply to all touring vehicles in the City of Beaufort Historic District. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04) 


Sec. 7-11002. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the following terms, where used in this chapter, shall 
have the meanings ascribed herein. 
    Historic district: The area corresponding to the Beaufort Historic District, bounded by Boundary 
Street on the north, the Beaufort River on the east and south, and Hamar and Bladen Streets on the west. 
    Nontouring vehicle: A commercial, chartered, or institutionally affiliated vehicle used only for the 
purpose of transporting passengers including, but not limited to, school buses used for transporting 
students; vehicles used for public transportation; and vehicles traveling only on perimeter roads or to 
destinations on perimeter roads for shopping, dining, touring on foot, or off-loading onto a registered 
touring vehicle. 
    Special permit: May be issued for (a) prior commitments, or (b) specific nontouring purposes for 
transporting passengers. 
    Tour: A visitation for hire by any means for purposes of sightseeing, which originates or is conducted 
within the Beaufort city limits. A tour shall include, but not be limited to, such visitation for hire on foot, 
conveyance by motorized or human-powered vehicle, or by animal-drawn carriage for such purpose. 
Transportation whose primary purpose is point-to-point conveyance or which offers no commentary or 
narration and which does not involve stops for any purpose of viewing is not considered a tour under 
these regulations. 
    Tour coordinator or coordinator: The person or agency designated by the city manager responsible 
for coordinating tours within the historic district. 
    Touring vehicle: A commercial, chartered, or institutionally affiliated vehicle transporting passengers 
whose major purpose is to visit or drive by historic sights, cultural attractions, or scenic areas within the 
historic district. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04) 


Sec. 7-11003. - Tourism management advisory commission (TMAC). 
(a) ?There is hereby created the City of Beaufort Tourism Management Advisory Commission (TMAC). 
This commission shall be appointed by the city council and shall consist of seven (7) members 
representing all areas of the city affected by the tours. 
(b) ?Commission members shall serve in an ad hoc manner and shall be appointed when deemed 
necessary by city council. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-02-09, 1-27-09; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11004. - Powers and duties of the tourism management advisory commission (TMAC). 
    The primary duty of the commission is to gather and analyze information and advise city council on 
tourism-related matters. Other duties include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1) ?Formulating recommendations regarding policies for registering vehicles and scheduling and 
assigning routes; 
(2) ?Formulating recommendations regarding limits on the number of vehicles permitted per day in 
sensitive areas; 
(3) ?Formulating recommendations on tour routes and on fees and modifications to this chapter; 
(4) ?Conduct a review of the tourism management ordinance every three (3) years and make 
recommendations to city council regarding changes; 
(5) ?Coordinate with educational, business and civic interests to establish and maintain a clearly 
defined vision for the future of tourism in the city; and 
(6) ?Other appropriate duties as assigned by city council. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04) 


Sec. 7-11005. - Fees 
(a) ?City council shall have the authority to levy fees for sightseeing tours oriented or conducted within 
the city limits. 
(b) ?The city manager shall designate the appropriate city government to collect all fees. 
(c) ?All touring fees collected shall be used for tourism-related expenses including, but not limited to, 
salaries, parking, signage and chamber fees. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04) 


Sec. 7-11006. - Special permits/special events. 
(a) ?Special permits. Special permits may be issued to groups with specific nontouring purposes as 
follows: 
(1) ?Special permits for transporting passengers to noncommercial areas in the historic district. 
a. ?Vehicles transporting passengers to a prearranged destination within the sensitive areas 
must register with the tour coordinator prior to the date of the trip. 
b. ?All requests must include the following: name of group, destination, name of 
agency/organization sponsoring group, reason for request and agreement from 
owner/representative for final destination. 
(2) ?Upon approval of a request a special temporary permit and placard will be issued by the tour 
coordinator. The permit shall be placed prominently on the passenger side of the front 
windshield or as recommended by the tour coordinator. 
(b) ?Special events. The city manager or his designee may approve exceptions to this chapter regarding 
routes, maximum number of touring vehicles, and hours of operation. The city manager shall 
maintain a standard operating procedure for special events, which shall be issued to all applicants 
for a special events permit, and which shall become a condition of such permit. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08) 


Sec. 7-11007. - Business licenses. 
(a) ?All tour companies which have a fixed place of business within the city limits, require a certified tour 
guide, purchase a rotation slot, or originate tours within the city limits must obtain a business license 
from the City of Beaufort. 
(b) ?All tour companies applying for a business license with the City of Beaufort are subject to review by 
TMAC prior to issuance of a business license. 


Sec. 7-11008. - Enforcement. 
    The city manager shall designate the appropriate agency within city government to enforce the 
provisions of this chapter. Violations of this chapter shall carry a fine of not less than one hundred dollars 
($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per occurrence. Tour operators or guides 
may contest their citations in municipal court. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


ARTICLE A. - TOUR COORDINATOR 


Sec. 7-11009. - Tour coordinator. 
(a) ?Appointment. The city manager shall designate a tour coordinator who shall be responsible for 
coordinating tours within the historic district. 
(b) ?Authority to regulate. The tour coordinator shall have the authority to promulgate regulations 
pertaining to this chapter subject to the review and approval of the city manager. 
(c) ?Enforcement. The tour coordinator shall have the authority to issue a citation to any tour operators 
and/or tour guides for violations of this chapter. Each citation shall carry a fine of not less than one 
hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per occurrence. Tour 
operators may contest their citations in municipal court. 
(d) ?Duties. Duties of the coordinator include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1) ?Registering vehicles; 
(2) ?Assigning routes and starting times for touring vehicles; 
(3) ?Handling correspondence with bus companies, tour operators, and tourism agencies; 
(4) ?Granting special permits to companies and organizations; 
(5) ?Submit a budget annually to the city manager for funding to cover the costs involved in 
administering this program; 
(6) ?Maintain liaison with the tourism management advisory commission on matters related to 
tourism; and 
(7) ?Shall be the first point of contact for tour operators with questions about this ordinance. 
(8) ?Provide written quarterly reports to the city manager, chief of police and tourism management 
advisory commission on the number and nature of violations reported or observed, the tour 
company associated with each report (if known), action taken by the tour coordinator and the 
number of citations issued, amount of fines levied, number of special tour requests, number of 
certification examinations given, and the information on accidents or medical, public safety or 
criminal incidents associated with touring activities, including any suspensions or revocations of 
tour company business licenses or tour certifications. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08) 


Sec. 7-11010. - Tourism management point system. 
(a) ?A point system will be enacted as follows which shall apply to all tour companies operating within 
the city: 
Tour guide certification. A record will be established for all certified tour guides upon receipt of a
