citation under this ordinance [chapter]. Anyone being found or pleading guilty in municipal court to a 
violation of the tourism management ordinance will be assessed one point per conviction. Points will 
accumulate on a rolling annual basis from the date of conviction. Certified tour guides accumulating 
more than three (3) points in any year will forfeit their tour guide certification and return it to the tour 
vehicle coordinator. Any previously certified tour guide will be unable to reapply for tour guide 
certification for one year from forfeiture. 
Tour operators. A record will be established for all bona fide tour operators licensed under the 
ordinance. Any bona fide tour operator being found or pleading guilty or no contest in municipal court 
to a violation of the tourism management ordinance will be assessed one point per conviction. Points 
will accumulate on a rolling annual basis from the date of conviction. 
Tour operators will also accrue points as follows for individual tour guides in their employ at the time 
of citation per the following schedule: 
Any individual tour guide incurring three (3) tour guide citations with subsequent conviction = one 
point to the tour operator. 
Any tour company accumulating more than three (3) points in any year will forfeit their touring 
privileges, including any fees previously paid to the city. The tour operator forfeiting their touring 
privileges will be unable to subsequently purchase the slot they have relinquished for one year. If the 
slot vacated remains open, the operator may apply to repurchase one year after the date of 
forfeiture. 
The tour vehicle coordinator will also be able to assess points for nonpayment of fees and 
noncompliance with record requirements (i.e., veterinary records, inspections, quarterly reports, etc.) 
if not completed as per the required schedule. The tour vehicle coordinator will issue a schedule at 
the beginning of each calendar year as to due dates and requirements. Each violation issued by the 
tour vehicle coordinator under the point system will accrue in one point increments and will be 
accumulated from the date of point issuance on an annual basis. 
(b) ?Notwithstanding subsection (a) above, it shall be unlawful for, and the tour vehicle coordinator shall 
issue citations for, any employee of a tour company to commit deliberate and malicious acts to the 
property or operations of another tour company, such acts to include, but not be limited to, tampering 
with another company's equipment, marking of spills where no spill has occurred, manually 
depositing manure on the street to require clean-up, defacing or altering any city-owned property or 
equipment (i.e., the wet bulb thermometer, or the kiosk), removing or modifying the contents of the 
"Spills" log kept in the kiosk. Any conviction guilty or no contest plea to a citation in this section shall 
result in the immediate forfeiture of the touring privileges for both the individual and the company by 
which they are employed, without regard to prior points accumulated per subsection (a) above. 
(Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11011. - Quarterly reporting of tour activities. 
    With the exception of large vehicle operators, each bona fide company operating a touring business 
will remit a quarterly report to the tour vehicle coordinator on the number of tours conducted and the 
number of people on tour. These numbers will be provided by aggregate category in the quarterly tour 
vehicle coordinator report to provide data to TMAC and the city regarding tour operations. 
(Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


ARTICLE B. - TOUR CERTIFICATION 


Sec. 7-11012. - Definitions. 
    Tour: A visitation for hire by any means for purposes of sightseeing, which originates or is conducted 
within the Beaufort city limits. A tour shall include, but not be limited to, such visitation for hire on foot, 
conveyance by motorized or human-powered vehicle, or by animal-drawn carriage for such purpose. 
Transportation whose primary purpose is point-to-point conveyance or which offers no commentary or 
narration and which does not involve stops for any purpose of viewing is not considered a tour under 
these regulations. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11013. - Business licenses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a tour within the city limits of Beaufort, South Carolina, 
unless such person either holds a current business license granted by the City of Beaufort, is employed 
by a tour company which holds a current business license for such activity, or has hired a certified tour 
guide to narrate the tour. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11014. - Certification. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to act or offer to act as a tour guide for hire within the city limits 
unless he or she has been certified by the City of Beaufort under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11015. - Application. 
(a) ?Any person desiring tour guide certification shall submit an application in writing to the tour 
coordinator on a form to be supplied by the tour coordinator. 
(b) ?An applicant for tour guide must not be less than eighteen (18) years of age and must provide the 
following materials: 
(1) ?Positive identification. 
(2) ?A current, valid driver's license if applicable to operate motorized or carriage tours. 
(3) ?A recent photograph. 
(4) ?Proof of successfully passing the City of Beaufort certification examination. 
(c) ?All applicants will submit to a background investigation to be completed by the Beaufort Police 
Department and state law enforcement division (SLED). The background investigation through SLED 
will be at the applicant's expense. 
(d) ?Any applicant that has been convicted of a felony or violation of laws involving moral turpitude will 
not be eligible for licensing. Any applicant that has pending charges of the same will not have their 
application processed until final disposition of the charges. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11016. - Issuance of certification. 
    Upon successfully meeting all of the requirements under this article and the passage of the 
competency examination for tour guide certification, the tour coordinator shall issue to the applicant a 
photographic identification card indicating that the holder is a certified tour guide. 
(a) ?The identification card must be visible at all times when conducting a tour. 
(b) ?The identification card shall remain the property of the city and must be returned upon 
expiration, revocation, or suspension of the certification. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11017. - Competency examination. 
(a) ?No person shall be issued a tour guide certification card unless that person has passed the tour 
guide certification examination given by the tour coordinator. The examination shall be given not less 
than quarterly and shall test the applicant's knowledge of the following: 
(1) ?The history and architecture of the City of Beaufort. 
(2) ?The local government. 
(3) ?The proper conduct of tour guides. 
(4) ?The regulations applicable to the conduct of tours within the city. 
(b) ?The fee for the initial and subsequent tour guide certification examination shall be determined by 
city council. Individuals are limited to taking the certification exam four (4) times in any six-month 
period. 
(c) ?Dates for administration of the examination shall be announced and published by the tour 
coordinator. 
(d) ?Applicants shall be provided with a tour guide manual and a list of source material from which 
examination questions may be taken. 
(e) ?To protect the privacy and security of individuals living along tour routes, tour guides are expressly 
prohibited from providing information on the identity, residency status (i.e., full-time/part-time), 
occupation, or number of household occupants along any route. 
(f) ?Successful passage of the tour guide certification examination shall be upon a grade of eighty (80) 
percent or greater. Upon each successful passage, a certified tour card shall be issued for a period 
of three (3) years, during which time the applicant shall not be required to take the examination 
again. 
(g) ?At the expiration of the three-year period, the certified tour guide shall be required to submit a new 
background investigation through SLED, as stipulated in section 7-11015. They shall also be 
required to take and similarly pass the tour guide certification examination again before being issued 
a new tour guide certification for another three-year period. 
(h) ?All examination papers shall be fairly and impartially graded and shall be retained by the tour 
coordinator until the appeal period provided hereinafter has expired. 
(i) ?A tour guide certification shall be in effect for thirty-six (36) months from the date of issue. 
Certification may be renewed, upon application and payment of the required fee, for each thirty-six-
month period thereafter, unless the permit for the proceeding period has been revoked or is 
suspended. 
(j) ?A tour guide certification identification card issued under this article is not transferable and is to be 
used solely by the person to whom it was issued. 
(k) ?It shall be unlawful to alter, deface, obliterate or destroy a tour guide verification identification card 
or cause or allow the same. 
(l) ?Each tour guide will have a minimum of one tour every three (3) years audited on an unannounced 
basis for content accuracy and operating regulation compliance by the tour vehicle coordinator or a 
member of TMAC. The audit is nonpunitive in nature and will include suggestions for improved 
accuracy and content and compliance with operating regulations. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-31-06, 9-26-06; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-
28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11018. - Appeals. 
    Any decision by the tour coordinator to deny a license for an individual seeking to become a certified 
tour guide may be appealed to the city manager within ten (10) business days of the decision. The 
decision of the city manager shall be final and binding. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11019. - Suspension and/or revocation. 
(a) ?Upon the recommendation of the tour coordinator, the city manager may suspend or cause the 
suspension of a tour guide certification for the following reasons: 
(1) ?Making false statements in the application for the tour guide certification. 
(2) ?Operating a tour service or vehicle in violation of any provision of this article or state law. 
(b) ?Any person aggrieved by the suspension or revocation of a tour guide certification may appeal the 
decision to the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11020. - Exemption of nonprofit organizations. 
    The tour coordinator shall have the authority to exempt nonprofit organizations from these 
regulations in order to conduct special, nonrecurring tours for a limited duration of time. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11021. - Enforcement. 
    The city manager shall designate the appropriate agency within city government to enforce the 
enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. Violations of this chapter shall carry a fine of not less than 
one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per occurrence. Tour 
operators or guides may contest their citations in municipal court. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11022. - Communication equipment required. 
    Tour companies shall furnish each of their tour guides or vehicle operators with a two-way radio or 
mobile telephone for immediate communication with the company's home office or emergency 
responders. Tour guides and/or vehicle operators shall maintain this communication equipment on their 
person at all times during a tour. 
(Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


ARTICLE C. - TOUR VEHICLES 


Sec. 7-11023. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the following terms, where used in this chapter, shall 
have the meanings ascribed herein: 
    Debark: To exit from a touring vehicle. 
    Debarkation: The process of exiting from a touring vehicle. 
    Embark: To enter a touring vehicle. 
    Embarkation: The process of entering a touring vehicle. 
    Historic district: The area bounded by Boundary Street on the north, the Beaufort River on the east 
and south, and Hamar and Bladen Streets on the west. 
    Large vehicle: Any vehicle used for touring with an official exterior length greater than twenty-five 
and one-half (25½) feet. 
    Mid-sized vehicle: Any vehicle used for touring with an official exterior length of twenty-five and one-
half (25½) feet or less. As used in this chapter this term includes standard passenger automobiles, or 
electric vehicles as well. 
    Nontouring vehicle: A commercial, chartered, or institutionally affiliated vehicle used only for the 
purpose of transporting passengers including, but not limited to, school buses used for transporting 
students; vehicles used for public transportation; and vehicles traveling only on perimeter roads or to 
destinations on perimeter roads for shopping, dining, touring on foot, or off-loading onto a registered 
touring vehicle. 
    Perimeter roads: Bay Street, Bladen Street, Boundary Street, and Carteret Street. 
    Point area: The area east of Carteret Street, bounded by Washington Street to the north, Bay Street 
to the south. 
    Restricted areas: All roads in the historic district that are neither perimeter roads nor part of tour 
routes for the particular class of vehicle. Hence, restricted areas vary for the two (2) classes of vehicles. 
    Sensitive areas: All roads in the historic district except perimeter roads. 
    Special permit: May be issued for (a) prior commitments, or (b) specific nontouring purposes for 
transporting passengers. 
    Theme vehicle: A vehicle whose design, shape, form, color, signage, or accoutrements is intended to 
create a particular identity and to call special attention to that vehicle, such as a trolley, pedi cab, snail 
vehicle, or articulated vehicle. Touring vehicles displaying commercial or institutional identification in a 
customary fashion shall not be considered theme vehicles. 
    Tour coordinator or coordinator: The person or agency designated by the city manager responsible 
for coordinating touring vehicles within the historic district. 
    Touring vehicle: A commercial, chartered, or institutionally affiliated vehicle transporting passengers 
whose main purpose is to visit or drive by historic sights, cultural attractions, or scenic areas within the 
historic district. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11024. - Theme vehicles. 
    Theme vehicles other than horse-drawn carriages may not be utilized for touring purposes in the 
historic district. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11025. - Registration. 
(a) ?Operators of the following types of vehicles must register with the tour coordinator or designee prior 
to beginning a tour in the historic district or traveling in the historic district: 
(1) ?All touring vehicles. 
(2) ?All large nontouring vehicles (over twenty-five and one-half (25½) feet in length). 
Exceptions: 
a. ?Vehicles which are traveling only on perimeter roads and only to destinations beyond the 
historic district; 
b. ?Vehicles used for public transportation; and 
c. ?School buses used for transporting students. 
(b) ?Operators of vehicles specified in (a) above shall supply the following information to the tour 
coordinator when registering: 
(1) ?Name and company of certified tour guide narrating tour; 
(2) ?Name of the tour operator or tour sponsor; 
(3) ?Origin and final destination of the trip; 
(4) ?Estimated duration of the stay and destinations in Beaufort; 
(5) ?Number of passengers on the vehicle (or estimated number when registering in advance, if the 
exact number is not known); and 
(6) ?Official specification for the vehicle exterior length. 
(c) ?The tour coordinator may request additional information, as appropriate. 
(d) ?A permit will be given for all touring vehicles which must be prominently displayed on the passenger 
side of the front windshield or as recommended by the tour coordinator. 
(e) ?The tour coordinator will assign a route and may, in cases where routes are at or near capacity, as 
determined by the coordinator or by policy when so established, assign a departure time for the route 
(the earliest available time). Operators are encouraged to schedule tours ahead of time. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11026. - Vehicle classifications. 
    Touring vehicles shall be classified as one of the following for the purposes of this chapter: 
(a) ?Large vehicle: Any vehicle used for touring with an exterior length greater than twenty-five and 
one-half (25½) feet. 
(b) ?Mid-sized vehicle: Any vehicle used for touring with an exterior length of twenty-five and one-
half (25½) feet or less. As used in this chapter, this term includes standard passenger 
automobiles, or electric vehicles as well. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11027. - Routes. 
    The tour coordinator in consultation with the city manager shall establish routes for each class of 
vehicle. 
(1) ?The tour coordinator shall assign routes in order to minimize congestion on the streets and 
avoid unfair burdens upon residents of streets along which a preponderance of vehicles might 
otherwise travel. 
(2) ?Assigned routes for mid-sized vehicles can be cut short at any perimeter road and at Charles 
Street. Assigned routes for large vehicles can be cut short at any perimeter road provided no 
shortcuts are taken outside of the assigned route to reach those roads. 
(3) ?Assigned large vehicle routes may contain optional turnoffs which can be followed if the driver 
of the vehicle chooses. 
(4) ?In cases where a road or an intersection along the assigned route is impassable for any reason 
the driver of a touring vehicle shall follow the most direct alternative path around that road or 
intersection. 
(5) ?Touring vehicles shall not enter those street ends designated by the city as public vistas. 
(6) ?Large vehicles shall not be permitted east of Carteret Street. 
(7) ?Mid-sized vehicles with width exceeding ten (10) feet, a wheel base exceeding sixteen (16) feet 
and exceeding ten (10) feet in height are not permitted east of Carteret Street. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11028. - Vehicle movement and stopping. 
    Touring vehicles must continue moving at all times and may not stop except as required by traffic 
regulations and at designated embarkation/debarkation points (as specified below) and parking areas. 
Vehicles may not operate in reverse except where necessary to maneuver at intersections, 
embarkation/debarkation points, and parking areas. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11029. - Idling. 
    Idling of engines is allowed only while passengers are embarking onto or debarking from vehicles, 
not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes, with exceptions as noted below. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11030. - Embarkation and debarkation. 
(a) ?Large and mid-sized vehicles. Passengers may be discharged and/or picked up only at the 
embarkation/debarkation points designated below: 
(1) ?The east side of Newcastle Street south of King Street at St. Helena's Episcopal Church. 
(2) ?The south side of Bay Street in the paved shoulder located just west of Monson Street, 
opposite the courthouse. Vehicles may idle in this location for up to ten (10) minutes at a time 
whether passengers are embarking/debarking or not. 
(3) ?The Marina Parking Lot. The limitation on idling, above, does not apply. 
(4) ?The Chamber of Commerce Visitor's Center allocated bus parking on Carteret Street, one 
parking spot south of Craven Street and one parking spot north of Craven Street. 
(b) ?Mid-sized vehicles. Passengers may embark/debark from mid-sized vehicles at the locations listed 
above as well as the following: 
(1) ?The loading zone on Scott Street, south of Port Republic Street, provided there is no truck 
parked in the zone at that time. Maximum length of stop is fifteen (15) minutes. 
(2) ?A spot to be determined by the city, Visitor's Convention Bureau and SCDOT near the visitor's 
center. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11031. - Short-term parking. 
    Short-term parking of touring vehicles is permitted in locations designated by the city for a maximum 
of two (2) hours. Idling is not permitted except while passengers are embarking or debarking and shall not 
exceed fifteen (15) minutes. (Idling exemptions listed in section 7-11030 do apply). 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11032. - Long-term parking. 
(a) ?There is no limit on idling in the Marina Parking Lot, or in other designated areas specifically 
designated by the tour vehicle coordinator, except that engines may not be left idling overnight. 
(b) ?All touring vehicles must register at the visitor's center. 
(c) ?Nontouring vehicles may park in designated bus spaces, as available, with prior approval of the tour 
coordinator. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11033. - Amplification. 
    Speaker phones and amplification devices may be operated only within the confines of an enclosed 
vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11034. - Hours. 
(a) ?Tours may be conducted in sensitive areas of the historic district during the following hours only: 
(1) ?Monday through Saturday: 9:30 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. 
(2) ?Sundays, Christmas, and Thanksgiving: 12:00 noon to 6:00 p.m. (Purchaser may be required 
to obtain permit prior to holidays.) 
(3) ?Preregistered large vehicles: Preregistered large vehicles arriving prior to scheduled tour day 
(Monday through Saturday) may begin at 9:00 a.m. 
(b) ?No tour on Thursday may begin after 5:30 p.m. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11035. - Fees. 
(a) ?Any vehicle requiring a commercial driver's license for operators engaged in bringing passengers to 
the City of Beaufort for the purpose of sightseeing or touring must pay a per vehicle permit fee which 
will be determined by city council. 
(b) ?The tour coordinator shall have the authority to exempt nonprofit organizations from these 
regulations in order to conduct special, nonrecurring tours for a limited duration of time. 
(c) ?All bona fide licensed tour vehicle operators may be entitled to purchase one embarkation rotation 
slot for an annual fee to be determined by city council. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11036. - Business licenses. 
    Vehicles which are based in Beaufort or collect revenue within the city limits must be licensed and 
are subject to the provisions of Part 7, Chapter 4 of this Code, Licensing and Regulation—Public 
Conveyances. 
(a) ?Fixed place of business. Each bona fide tour bus company, as a condition for holding a license 
under the provisions of this chapter, shall establish and maintain a fixed headquarters on public 
or private property for the operation of the company's business. The headquarters shall conform 
to the ordinances of the city; and adequate off-street parking space shall be provided for all tour 
buses waiting or not in service. 
(b) ?Inspection. Each new bus shall be inspected by the tour coordinator for compliance before 
being placed into passenger service. Each passenger vehicle shall be inspected annually upon 
renewal of the owner's city business license. In addition, any bus involved in an accident shall 
be inspected by the tour coordinator prior to being returned to service transporting passengers 
for hire. The current city taxi permit will then be affixed upon satisfactory inspection of the 
vehicle. 
(c) ?Failure to comply. Any applicant who fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter shall 
not be issued or reissued a business license until proof of compliance is presented by the 
applicant and certified by the tour coordinator, police, or codes enforcement officer. All of the 
requirements of this chapter both serve as conditions for issuance of a license and apply to the 
business once operational. 
(d) ?Suspension of license. The city manager may temporarily suspend the business license of any 
bus company for violation of any provision of this ordinance. The tour company may appeal any 
such suspension to city council provided a written appeal has been submitted to the city 
manager within seven (7) days of the city manager's decision. 
(e) ?Determination of bona fide operator status. The city manager shall determine whether a 
company which applies for a bona fide tour vehicle operator's license is, indeed a stand-alone 
company, with separate ownership, management and equipment. Existing bus tour companies 
shall not be given a license to operate for a new company created in name only. 
(f) ?Limitations on business licenses. No more than four (4) bona fide tour bus companies shall be 
licensed to operate in the city. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11037. - Taxi permit. 
    Holders of a city business license for the operation of tour bus upon the streets of the city shall be 
assigned a current year city taxi permit which will be maintained by the business license office. The taxi 
permit number shall be attached on the left rear of the vehicle and shall be permanently displayed 
thereon. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11038. - Driver's permit. 
(a) ?No tour company within the city limits that owns or operates a tour bus company shall permit a tour 
bus to be driven at any time for hire unless the driver of the bus shall first have obtained, and 
maintains, a valid tour driver's permit issued by the city. Driver's permits will be issued and records 
will be maintained by the police department. 
(b) ?On approval of any driver's permit the chief of police, or his designated agent, shall issue a card 
which shall bear on its face a photograph of the permittee, permit number, expiration date, name of 
tour company or corporation hiring the driver, and any other information as the chief of police may 
direct. 
(c) ?Driver's permits shall be for a period of three (3) years from the date of issue. The cost of the 
driver's permit shall be determined by city council. 
(d) ?The driver's permit card shall, at all times, be kept on display in the vehicle operated by the driver, 
easily visible for the passenger, while that permittee is in control of the vehicle. 
(e) ?The driver's permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall not be transferable between individuals or 
companies. 
(f) ?Every applicant for a permit under the provisions for this chapter shall be at least eighteen (18) years 
of age. 
(g) ?Revocation of permit. Any driver's permit granted under the terms of this chapter may be suspended 
by the chief of police for any violation of this chapter and after due notice to the permittee in writing, 
citing him to appear before the chief of police and show cause why his permit should not be 
permanently revoked. The chief of police may revoke the city driver's permit of any driver when, in 
his judgment, the driver's physical condition or record for violation of traffic laws, city ordinances, 
moral turpitude, or other state and federal laws applicable to public passenger service vehicles which 
indicates the permittee an unfit operator of such a public passenger vehicle or carriage. 
(h) ?Appeal from permit revocation. Any person dissatisfied with the decision of the chief of police shall 
have the right of appeal to the city manager. Any such appeal must be submitted in writing to the city 
manager within seven (7) days from the date that the decision by the chief of police is rendered. The 
decision of the city manager is final. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11039. - Insurance. 
(a) ?Any company offering vehicle tours in the City of Beaufort shall be required to provide proof of 
insurance at the time of business license application and upon request by any inspecting agent of 
the City of Beaufort. 
(b) ?Insurance requirements shall be set by city council. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11040. - Design standards. 
(a) ?All buses must be reviewed by tour coordinator prior to issuance of business license. 
(b) ?Buses must not be themed in any way. 
(1) ?Any standard design bus will be allowed. 
(2) ?Colors of the bus must be reasonable. 
(3) ?No loud or gaudy colors are allowed. 
(4) ?No florescent paint schemes. 
(5) ?No graphic wraps will be allowed. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11041. - Identification of buses and posting of information. 
(a) ?Information on the vehicle's official gross weight and dimensions shall be maintained with the 
vehicle whenever the vehicle is in operation. The vehicle's official rated capacity for number of 
passengers shall be conspicuously posted on or in the vehicle. 
(b) ?The name of the tour company shall be clearly displayed on both sides of every vehicle in letters not 
less than two (2) inches in height. A number not less than four (4) inches in height shall be clearly 
displayed on both sides and on the rear of every vehicle. The number shall be assigned by the tour 
coordinator and it shall be distinct from numbers assigned to all other tour companies in the city. 
(Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11042. - Posting of rate card. 
    All persons owning, driving, operating or controlling a tour bus, shall post a rate card therein, in a 
conspicuous place where it may be easily and conveniently read by any passenger. The card shall 
display in plain legible type rates to be charged for transporting passengers or touring. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11043. - Condition of tour buses. 
(a) ?Each tour bus operated on the streets of the city shall be maintained in a safe mechanical condition, 
with all safety equipment remaining intact and operative at all times when the bus is in service. 
(b) ?Each bus shall be kept painted and in a clean and sanitary condition, free of litter and debris and, at 
all times, suitable for public transportation of passengers. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11044. - Traffic related regulations. 
    Whenever three (3) or more motor vehicles are backed up behind a tour bus the driver shall, at his 
earliest reasonable opportunity, pull the vehicle over to the side of the road to allow those vehicles to 
pass. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11045. - General operating regulations. 
(a) ?The total number of touring buses allowed to operate at any one time upon the streets of the city is 
limited to six (6). 
(b) ?Spacing of tour vehicles. In order to relieve congestion on the streets and to mitigate impact upon 
residents and businesses no more than one touring vehicle (whether bus or horse-drawn carriage) 
shall be driven along any three-block section in the same direction at any one time. A three-block 
section is herein defined as that linear segment of any individual street circumscribed by four (4) 
contiguous intersecting streets. Where these spacing requirements are not met, the drivers of the 
last tour vehicles to enter that section shall generally be deemed to have committed the violation. 
(c) ?No driver shall permit more passengers to be carried in a bus than the rated seating capacity of the 
vehicle. A child in arms shall not be counted as a passenger. 
(d) ?No driver shall collect fares, make change, or take on or discharge passengers when the vehicle is 
in motion. It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit passengers verbally or by gesture, directly or 
indirectly, or to advertise or hawk tickets at any loading zone, upon the streets, or in any public 
outdoor space of the city. 
(e) ?It shall be unlawful to consume or transport alcoholic beverages aboard any tour vehicle. 
(f) ?A driver may refuse service to any potential customer who appears to be impaired or disorderly. 
(g) ?Any driver or operator discovering personal property left on his vehicle shall deliver or report such 
property to the office of the tour company within twelve (12) hours after the discovery. The driver's 
report shall include brief particulars to enable the company to identify the owner of the lost property. 
The driver will advise any passenger claiming to have lost property while on tours to report such loss 
to the police. The company shall retain any found property for at least sixty (60) days before 
disposal. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11046. - Embarkation rotation slots. 
(a) ?Definition of rotation slots. A rotation slot entitles the holder to one place in the embarkation queue 
for a twelve-month period, as follows: if there are less than four (4) operators who hold one rotation 
slot each, then each operator will alternate embarkation departures on an equal basis. 
(b) ?Fees associated with rotation slots. Slot fees will be assessed annually, the cost of which will be 
determined by city council. 
(c) ?Bus tours subject to the embarkation queuing system. All mid-sized touring vehicles that depart from 
the designated departure areas are subject to the rules and regulations of the embarkation queuing 
system. All mid-sized touring vehicles shall be issued a copy of the Bus Rotation Slot System 
Standard Operating Procedures (as approved in November 2005 or as amended), and shall comply 
with these operating procedures. The original of such procedures shall be maintained in the office of 
the tour vehicle coordinator. 
(d) ?Bus tours exempt from the embarkation queuing system. Point-to-point tours which originate and 
terminate at locations other than the designated departure areas are exempt from the queuing 
system. Special events as defined in this chapter are exempt from the queuing system with a special 
permit. Large vehicles that do not tour the point area. All touring vehicles will be subject to 
appropriate fees and registration requirements. 
(e) ?Allocation of rotation slots. Four (4) permanent rotation slots will be allocated for tours. Rotation 
slots will leave every fifteen (15) minutes. Embarkation rotation slots will rotate on a weekly basis 
unless otherwise mutually agreed to in writing by those holding a slot. 
(f) ?Purchase of rotation slots. Each bona fide licensed tour bus operator shall be entitled to the 
noncompetitive purchase of one embarkation rotation slot for an annual fee determined by city 
council. Should either of the licensed tour bus operators cease to operate for a period of more than 
sixty (60) consecutive days, the rotation slot shall be forfeited and the slot shall be open and 
available for purchase in the same manner. 
(g) ?A maximum of two (2) nonlocal mid-sized vehicles will be permitted to register to tour in the historic 
district provided they have a licensed tour guide and meet all other mid-sized touring vehicle 
requirements. These nonlocal mid-sized vehicles may conduct a maximum of eight (8) tours per 
month and may conduct their tour without regard to embarkation slot timing. They will be subject to 
tour routes as designated by the tour vehicle coordinator. 
(h) ?Administration of rotation slots. Administration of the rotation slot system shall be provided by the 
tour coordinator or designee who shall have the authority to promulgate regulations for the rotation 
system subject to the review and approval of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04, Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-16-10, § 1, 9-28-10; Ord. 
No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11047. - Enforcement. 
    The city manager shall designate the appropriate agency within city government to enforce the 
enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. Violations of this chapter shall carry a fine of not less than 
one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per occurrence. Tour 
operators or guides may contest their citations in municipal court. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


ARTICLE D. - ANIMAL-DRAWN VEHICLES FOR HIRE 


Sec. 7-11048. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms mean: 
    City: A municipal corporation; the definition to include all areas within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Company: The holder of a license to operate a horse-drawn carriage business under the provisions 
of this chapter whether a person, firm, partnership or corporation. 
    Driver: Any person who drives or operates a horse-drawn carriage upon the streets of the city for a 
licensed carriage company. 
    Driver's permit: The written authority granted by the city and issued by the police department for an 
individual to drive or operate a horse-drawn carriage within the city. 
    Horse-drawn carriage: Any hack or carriage which is operated by being drawn by a horse, mule, or 
other beast of burden, for the transportation for hire of passengers. 
    Inspector: The individual employee or department of the city charged with the responsibility for 
administering and enforcing this chapter. 
    License: The right and privilege granted by the city for operation of a business incorporating the use 
of one or more horse-drawn carriages within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Special event: A prearranged tour to accommodate a one-time, nonrecurring special occasion such 
as a wedding party, celebration, convention or nonprofit activity. Large bus tours and boat tours shall not 
constitute a special event. 
    Street: Means and includes any street, alley, lane, avenue, court or public place or thoroughfare in 
the city. 
    Touring: Operation of a horse-drawn carriage for hire where the primary purpose is to drive by and 
see historic and architectural sites, cultural attractions, or scenic areas. 
    Vehicle for hire: Employment of a horse-drawn carriage for passengers, generally for a fee or a fare, 
for the purposes of touring, point-to-point transportation, or special events. The vehicle is not deemed to 
be "for hire" when such passengers are not on board. 
    Veterinarian: A veterinarian licensed in South Carolina who specializes in large animals. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11049. - Licensing of carriage companies. 
(a) ?Business license required. No person, firm or corporation shall operate a business involving the use 
of one or more horse-drawn carriages for hire upon the streets of the city unless a license for such 
business has first been granted by the city. 
(b) ?Right to inspection by veterinarian. The City of Beaufort shall reserve the right to have a licensed 
veterinarian inspect any animal actively used for the purpose of touring, with or without the 
permission of the tour company, at the expense of the city. 
(c) ?Required information. The carriage company shall give to the business license officer of the city the 
name, address, and telephone number of the veterinarian who certifies the health of the horses. The 
carriage company shall also maintain the following information on each horse and make this 
information available to the business license officer or the city manager or his designee upon 
request: 
(1) ?The current veterinarian examination record; 
(2) ?Annual immunization record including rabies and negative Coggins test. The following 
immunizations are required twice a year: eastern and western equine encephalomyelitis, 
tetanus, flu, west Nile and a health certificate stating the horse is in good health and able to 
haul; 
(3) ?A picture of the horse and a name or other designation for the horse; 
(4) ?Description of any identifying characteristics, marks, or brands; 
(5) ?The load/weight which each horse is capable of pulling as certified by a veterinarian. 
(d) ?Fixed place of business. Each horse-drawn carriage company, as a condition for holding a license 
under the provisions of this chapter, shall establish and maintain a fixed headquarters on public or 
private property for the operation of the company's business. The headquarters shall conform to the 
ordinances of the city; and adequate off-street parking space shall be provided for all horse-drawn 
carriages waiting or not in service. 
(e) ?Inspection. Each new carriage shall be inspected by police for compliance before being placed into 
passenger service. Each carriage shall be inspected annually upon renewal of the owner's city 
business license. In addition, any horse-drawn carriage involved in an accident shall be inspected by 
police prior to being returned to service transporting passengers for hire. The current city taxi permit 
will then be affixed upon satisfactory inspection of the vehicle and equipment. 
(f) ?Failure to comply. Any applicant who fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter shall not 
be issued or reissued a business license until proof of compliance is presented by the applicant and 
certified by the attending veterinarian, police, codes enforcement, or the tour coordinator. All of the 
requirements of this chapter both serve as conditions for issuance of a license and apply to the 
business once operational. 
(g) ?Suspension of license. The city manager may temporarily suspend the business license of any 
carriage company for violation of any provision of this ordinance. The carriage company may appeal 
any such suspension to city council provided a written appeal has been submitted to the city 
manager within seven (7) days of the city manager's decision. 
(h) ?Limitations on business licenses. No more than two (2) bona fide carriage companies shall be 
licensed to operate in the city. 
(i) ?Determination of bona fide operator status. The city manager shall determine whether a company 
which applies for a carriage tour operator's license is, indeed a stand-alone company, with separate 
ownership, management and equipment. Existing carriage tour companies shall not be given a 
license to operate for a new company created in name only. If city council, after notice and a hearing, 
determines that there exists collusion or other sharing of ownership between companies holding a 
license to operate carriage tours, said operator or operators shall be prohibited from participating in 
the sealed-bid procurement process set forth in section 7-11069(e) at the next license renewal 
period. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11050. - Taxi permit. 
    Holders of a city business license for the operation of horse-drawn carriages upon the streets of the 
city shall be assigned a current year city taxi permit which will be maintained by the business license 
office. The taxi permit number shall be attached on the left rear of the carriage and shall be permanently 
displayed thereon. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11051. - Driver's permit required. 
(a) ?No person shall operate a horse-drawn carriage for hire upon the streets of the city and no person 
who owns or operates a horse-drawn carriage company shall permit a horse-drawn carriage to be 
driven at any time for hire unless the driver of the carriage shall first have obtained, and maintains, a 
valid horse-drawn carriage driver's permit issued by the city. Driver's permits will be issued and 
records will be maintained by the police department. 
(b) ?Application. The driver of any horse-drawn carriage shall possess a valid driver's license and make 
and file with the chief of police a written application for a horse-drawn carriage driver's permit. Such 
application shall be sworn to by the applicant and shall include the full name, date of birth, driver's 
license state and number, and residence of the applicant; and shall state that the applicant 
possesses all requirements necessary to operate a horse-drawn carriage in a safe, prudent and 
satisfactory manner. A statement as to whether or not such applicant has been convicted of violating 
any provision of this chapter, or other city ordinance, state or federal law, and shall set forth the 
nature of the offense(s), if any, and furnish other information as may be required for determining the 
applicant's qualifications. Any false entry on the application will be cause for disapproval of the 
driver's permit. 
(c) ?Horse-drawn carriage driver's permits shall be for a period of three (3) years from the date of issue. 
The cost shall be determined by city council. 
(d) ?On approval of any driver's permit the chief of police, or his designated agent, shall issue a card 
which shall bear on its face a photograph of the permittee, permit number, expiration date, name of 
carriage company or corporation hiring the driver, and any other information as the chief of police 
may direct. 
(e) ?The driver's permit card shall, at all times, be kept on display in the carriage operated by the driver, 
easily visible for the passenger, while that permittee is in control of the carriage. 
(f) ?The driver's permit issued pursuant to this chapter, shall not be transferable between individuals or 
companies. 
(g) ?Every applicant for a permit under the provisions for this chapter shall be at least eighteen (18) 
years of age. 
(h) ?Revocation of permit. Any driver's permit granted under the terms of this chapter may be suspended 
by the chief of police for any violation of this chapter and after due notice to the permittee in writing, 
citing him to appear before the chief of police and show cause why his permit should not be 
permanently revoked. The chief of police may revoke the city driver's permit of any driver when, in 
his judgment, the driver's physical condition or record for violation of traffic laws, city ordinances, 
moral turpitude, or other state and federal laws applicable to public passenger service vehicles which 
indicates the permittee an unfit operator of such a public passenger vehicle or carriage. 
(i) ?Appeal from permit revocation. Any person dissatisfied with the decision of the chief of police shall 
have the right of appeal to the city manager. Any such appeal must be submitted in writing to the city 
manager within seven (7) days from the date that the decision by the chief of police is rendered. The 
decision of the city manager is final. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11052. - Insurance. 
(a) ?Any company offering horse-drawn vehicle tours in the City of Beaufort shall be required to provide 
proof of insurance at the time of business license application and upon request by any inspecting 
agent of the City of Beaufort. 
(b) ?Insurance requirements shall be set by city council. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11053. - Design standards. 
    Animal-drawn vehicles shall be authentically styled passenger carriages, similar to surreys, 
rockaways, or examples in illustrations number 1 through 40 in "American Carriages, Sleighs, Sulkies and 
Carts," ed. Don. K. Berkebik, Dover Publications, Inc. 1977. Wagons which patently were designed for 
cargo instead of passengers will not be approved. Carriages shall not exceed sixteen (16) feet in length 
or six (6) feet and four (4) inches in width. Carriages will be measured in length from end to end including 
the wheels but excluding the shaft. Carriages will be measured in width from outermost point to outermost 
point. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11054. - Identification of carriages/posting of information. 
(a) ?Information on the carriage vehicle's official gross weight and dimensions shall be maintained with 
the vehicle whenever the vehicle is in operation. The vehicle's official rated capacity for number of 
passengers shall be conspicuously posted on or in the vehicle. 
(b) ?The name of the carriage company shall be clearly displayed on both sides of every carriage in 
letters not less than two (2) inches in height. A number not less than four (4) inches in height shall be 
clearly displayed on both sides and on the rear of every carriage. The number shall be assigned by 
the business license official and it shall be distinct from numbers assigned to all other horse-drawn 
carriages in the city. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11055. - Posting of rate card. 
    All persons owning, driving, operating or controlling horse-drawn carriages, shall post a rate card 
therein, in a conspicuous place where it may be easily and conveniently read by any passenger. The card 
shall display in plain legible type rates to be charged for transporting passengers. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11056. - Condition of carriages. 
(a) ?Each horse-drawn carriage operated on the streets of the city shall be maintained in a safe 
mechanical condition, with all safety equipment remaining intact and operative at all times when the 
carriage is in service. 
(b) ?Carriages in operation thirty (30) minutes after sundown shall have lamps or reflectors in 
accordance with South Carolina Code 56-5-4650. 
(c) ?Each carriage shall be kept painted and in a clean and sanitary condition, free of litter and debris, 
and at all times, suitable for public transportation of passengers. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11057. - Safety equipment. 
    The following safety equipment shall be maintained on each carriage at all times: 
(1) ?A first aid kit. 
(2) ?A two-way radio or mobile telephone for immediate communication with the company's home 
office. 
(3) ?A "Slow Moving Vehicle" symbol mounted on the rear of the vehicle. 
(4) ?Headlights and taillights on each vehicle which meet or exceed the requirements of the State of 
South Carolina for vehicles. 
(5) ?Amber reflectors mounted on each side of the horse's bridle and harness and on each side of 
the horse-drawn carriage. 
(6) ?Brakes (each carriage shall be equipped with brakes). 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11058. - Sanitation requirements. 
    All carriage companies shall be issued a copy of, and shall comply with the standard operating 
procedures relating to clean-up, the original of which will be maintained in the office of the tour vehicle 
coordinator. Any spills or manure will be removed by the carriage operator. All spills must be marked with 
a water-soluble nontoxic marker at the time of the spill to allow for more effective clean-up. Spillage or 
manure not removed by the operator will be removed by the city, the cost of which will be borne by the 
operator on duty when reported. All horse-drawn carriages will have diaper bags appropriately attached 
and in good condition while operating on the streets in the City of Beaufort. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 
Cross reference— Health and sanitation generally, Title 6. 


Sec. 7-11059. - Traffic related regulations. 
    The operator of any animal-drawn vehicle within the city shall be subject to vehicle and traffic 
provisions of this ordinance and shall operate his or her carriage in accordance with the traffic laws of the 
state. 
(a) ?No driver shall permit an animal to pull a carriage at a speed faster than a slow trot, except in 
emergency situations. 
(b) ?Stopping along a tour route initiated by a carriage tour driver for purposes other than allowing 
for traffic or gaining control of the horse is prohibited. Additionally, prolonged stopping at traffic 
signs or signals, other than allowing for traffic or graining control of the horse, is prohibited. 
(c) ?Whenever three (3) or more motor vehicles are backed up behind a horse-drawn carriage the 
driver shall, at his earliest reasonable opportunity, pull the carriage over to the side of the road 
to allow those vehicles to pass. 
(d) ?All carriages for hire must keep moving at all times and may not stop except as required by 
traffic regulations and by subsection (b) above, and where particular exigencies reasonably 
require it. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11060. - General operating regulations. 
(a) ?The total number of horse-drawn carriages allowed to operate at any one time upon the streets of 
the city is limited to six (6) of which four (4) may be on tour. Any carriages in excess of the four (4) on 
tour shall only be permitted if it is in transport to or from their staging area. The carriages in operation 
shall be divided equally among the carriage companies. 
(b) ?Spacing of carriages. In order to relieve congestion on the streets and to mitigate impact upon 
residents and businesses no more than one touring vehicle (either bus or horse-drawn carriage) 
shall be driven along any three-block section in the same direction at any one time. A three-block 
section is defined as that linear segment of any individual street circumscribed by four (4) contiguous 
intersecting streets. Where these spacing requirements are not met, the drivers of the last carriages 
to enter that section shall generally be deemed to have committed the violation. This provision 
applies only to carriages while used for hire. However, drivers of carriages which are not being used 
for hire are encouraged to observe these spacing requirements. 
(c) ?No single animal shall pull a load greater than the load weight it is certified to pull by a licensed 
veterinarian. 
(d) ?No driver shall permit more passengers to be carried in a carriage than the rated seating capacity of 
the carriage. A child in arms shall not be counted as a passenger. 
(e) ?No driver shall collect fares, make change, or take on or discharge passengers when the carriage is 
in motion. 
(f) ?It shall be unlawful for a driver of any carriage to leave the vehicle, or the immediate premises 
thereof, while the vehicle is parked or while awaiting passengers at the carriage stand. 
(g) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit passengers verbally or by gesture, directly or indirectly, 
or to advertise or hawk tickets at any loading zone, upon the streets, or in any public outdoor space 
of the city. The sale of tour tickets may only occur at the carriage stand by the company which is in 
rotation, inside, on private property or other locations as designated by city council. 
(h) ?It shall be unlawful to consume or transport alcoholic beverages aboard any carriage. 
(i) ?A driver may refuse service to any potential customer who appears to be impaired or disorderly. 
(j) ?Any driver or operator discovering personal property left on his carriage shall deliver or report such 
property to the office of the carriage company within twelve (12) hours after the discovery. The 
driver's report shall include brief particulars to enable the company to identify the owner of the lost 
property. The driver will advise any passenger claiming to have lost property while on tours to report 
such loss to the police. The company shall retain any found property for at least sixty (60) days 
before disposal. 
(k) ?Carriages shall not be operated in adverse weather conditions. 
(l) ?Drivers must keep the horse reins in their hands at all times while the vehicle is touring, whether 
stopped or in motion. Drivers shall position themselves at no greater than a right angle to the front of 
the carriage while on tour and shall remain behind the dash of the carriage while in operation. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11061. - Carriage stands. 
(a) ?No parking of carriages shall be permitted in the corporate limits of the city except at designated 
carriage stands. Carriages may be parked at carriage stands for any length of time during the hours 
of operation stated in section 7-11063. 
(b) ?Designated carriage stands include the following: 
(1) ?In the west end of the Marina Parking Lot on Bay Street in the area adjacent to the water 
trough. 
(2) ?The city manager may designate additional stands in the Marina Parking lot. 
(c) ?No more than four (4) carriages at one time may be allowed in the Marina Parking Lot, the number 
of carriages shall be divided equally among the carriage companies present. Carriages awaiting an 
approved special event shall be excluded as approved by the tour coordinator. 
(d) ?Drivers of horse-drawn carriages shall maintain the carriage stands in a sanitary condition at all 
times. Any failure to do so on the part of the driver shall subject the driver and/or the company to the 
penalties provided herein. 
(e) ?The carriage kiosk located at the west end of the Marina Parking Lot on Bay Street adjacent to the 
water trough may only be used for the sale of carriage tickets and will be closed when carriage tour 
operations are shut down by the tour vehicle coordinator for weather conditions. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11062. - Loading zones. 
(a) ?Passengers may be loaded or discharged only in designated loading zones. Carriages may remain 
in loading zone only while loading or discharging passengers or while waiting to load passengers for 
a prearranged tour. However; no carriage may remain in a loading zone for more than ten (10) 
minutes without providing water to the horse. 
(b) ?The following locations are designated as loading zones: 
(1) ?Carriage stands designated by the city manager. 
(2) ?Location on private property (i.e., outside of the road right-of-way and any public areas) for 
prearranged tours, special events, and point-to-point transportation. 
(3) ?Location on street adjacent to homes, restaurants, hotels, churches, and other establishments 
for prearranged tours, special events, or point-to-point transportation for persons departing from 
or arriving at those establishments provided that there is no off-street parking otherwise 
available and that the carriage is parked outside of any travel lane. This allowance applies to 
Bay Street only after 5:30 p.m. 
(4) ?The city manager may establish additional loading zones and conditions for those loading 
zones. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11063. - Hours of operation. 
(a) ?Horse-drawn carriages for hire, including those used for tours, special events and point-to-point 
transportation (with exception in (b), below) shall be operated on the streets of the city only as 
follows: 
(1) ?Monday through Saturday, 9:40 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. 
(2) ?Sundays, Thanksgiving and Christmas, 12:00 noon to 6:00 p.m. 
(3) ?No tour on Thursday may commence after 5:30 p.m. 
(b) ?Point-to-point transportation shall also be permitted from 5:30 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. daily provided that 
the most expeditious route is followed and no touring is conducted. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11064. - Geographic area of operation and routes. 
(a) ?Area of operation. The permitted area of operation for horse-drawn carriages carrying passengers 
for touring, special events, or point-to-point transportation is defined as follows: 
(1) ?General boundaries for carriages for hire include all land bounded on the north by Boundary 
Street, on the east by the Beaufort River, on the south by Bay Street, and on the west by 
Bladen Street. 
(2) ?Carriages for hire are prohibited from operating on the following streets and street segments: 
Carteret Street, Boundary Street, Bay Street and street ends (short cul-de-sacs located in 
proximity to marsh areas) located east of Carteret Street. 
(3) ?Carriages for hire may only cross Carteret Street at electronically signalized intersections. 
(b) ?Routes. Routes are established as follows: 
(1) ?Carriages used for touring or for special events shall be operated only along approved routes 
and will be rotated on a weekly basis. Carriages used for point-to-point transportation are not 
restricted to these routes. 
(2) ?The tour coordinator may submit recommendations on routes to the city manager for his 
review. 
(3) ?Where particular exigencies exist drivers may deviate from the routes established herein 
provided they deviate from those routes as little as possible. 
(4) ?At times when carriages are not being operated for hire, drivers of those carriages are 
encouraged to travel along streets that are not part of the routes. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11065. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-03-08, adopted Feb. 12, 2008, deleted this section, which pertained 
to special events, and derived from Ord. No. O-13-04, adopted June 8, 2004. The same 
provisions can be found in § 7-11006. 


Sec. 7-11066. - Stables and exercise lots. 
    When stables or exercise lots are maintained within the city limits, the company shall comply with the 
following conditions: 
(a) ?Maintenance of structure and premises. The structure and premises shall be maintained in a 
sanitary condition through the proper use of lime and pesticides. 
(1) ?Manure shall be removed from the stable and lot at least twice daily and secured in plastic 
bags, then placed in covered containers or a Dempsey dumpster. Such containers shall be 
at least fifty (50) feet from any other dwelling or pool, patio or other structure on an 
adjoining lot and at least twenty-five (25) feet from any property line, notwithstanding any 
other provision contained in this chapter having requirements for covered containers. 
(2) ?All manure shall be removed from the premises at least twice weekly or more often as 
necessary to prevent or reduce the propagation of flies and creation of odors. 
(3) ?Exercise lots shall be designed and maintained to drain so as to prevent ponding and 
propagation of insects. The lot shall be designed and maintained so as to prevent the 
pollution by drainage or runoff into adjacent streams or other water bodies. 
(4) ?All feed spillage on the lot shall be promptly removed so as to prevent attraction of flies, 
rodents and birds, or the creation of odors. 
(5) ?Provisions shall also be made for insect control. 
(6) ?The exercise or training areas on the lot shall be dampened to prevent dust. 
(7) ?Any odors resulting from horses housed in the stable or lot shall not be detectable from 
the property line of the facility. 
(b) ?Welfare of horses. 
(1) ?Each individual draft animal shall have a stall large enough for the animal to safely turn 
around; but in no case shall any individual animal be kept in a stall less than ten (10) feet 
by twelve (12) feet or one hundred twenty (120) square feet in area. Ceilings in stalls and 
stables shall be at least nine (9) feet from the bedding and flooring. 
(2) ?Ventilation adequate to ensure good health and comfort of animals shall be provided in 
stable and stall areas. 
(3) ?Adequate and leak-free roofing is required for any stable or stall area in which animals are 
housed in the city. 
(4) ?Straw bedding in stalls and stables shall be kept at least six (6) inches in depth and shall 
not show wetness under the pressure of any draft animal's hooves. 
(5) ?Adequate water shall be provided in stables and stalls at all times while any draft animal is 
present. 
(6) ?Food shall be kept free of contamination and stored in rodent-proof containers. 
(c) ?Complaints. Complaints regarding any stable or lot that is not maintained in compliance with 
the foregoing requirements should be filed with the City of Beaufort building codes official. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11067. - Treatment and condition of horses. 
(a) ?A licensed veterinarian shall certify, after due and proper inspection, the good health of each draft 
animal before it is placed in service. A minimum of two (2) such health inspections and certificates, 
including a hoof exam, shall be required for each animal each calendar year. An equine veterinarian, 
without client relationship with either carriage operator, shall be selected by the tour vehicle 
coordinator (TVC). At such time as the TVC has substantial concern about the health, condition or 
treatment of any horse utilized in the operation of carriage tours, the TVC shall, in his/her sole 
discretion, request that this equine veterinarian conduct a spot check of all tour horses. The cost of 
such veterinarian services shall be billed to and borne equally by the carriage tour companies. 
(b) ?No driver may use more than a light touch of the whip upon any animal, and no driver or other 
person may forcefully strike an animal, or make movements or noise intended to frighten or harm an 
animal. 
(c) ?Horses shall be allowed access to water at least every one hour while in service and prior to 
commencing the first tour of the day. 
(d) ?No horse shall be permitted to be put into service for more than six (6) consecutive days. 
(e) ?No animal shall be subject to any condition or treatment, whether in service or out of service, which 
will impair the good health and physical condition of that animal. 
(f) ?Unless written approval is given by a licensed veterinarian, no animal having open sores or wounds 
or any disease or ailment, shall be permitted to be in service on the streets of the city. 
(g) ?Prompt veterinary care and services shall be provided for sick horses, and when deemed necessary 
by a licensed veterinarian, the sick horse shall be promptly removed from the facility. 
(h) ?Each draft animal utilized in carriage tours must have all hoof shoes properly attached or be 
properly enrolled in the Barefoot Program. 
(i) ?Each animal shall be groomed daily in order that there are no signs of fungus, dandruff, or a dirty 
coat. 
(j) ?Harnesses shall be properly fitted, maintained, and oiled so that no irritating material will come in 
direct contact with the animal. 
(k) ?Horse shall not be worked in extreme conditions of heat and humidity which may be harmful to the 
horse. Each carriage company shall be issued, and shall comply with, the document entitled "Care of 
Carriage Tour Draft Horses During Heat Conditions Standard Operating Procedure," the original of 
which document shall be maintained in the office of the tour vehicle coordinator. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11; Ord. No. O-
22-14, 8-12-14) 


Sec. 7-11068. - Inspections, compliance, and enforcement. 
(a) ?Any law enforcement officer, county health officer, the tour coordinator or codes enforcement official 
shall be empowered to inspect the stables, stalls, horses, carriages and other operating facilities of 
any carriage company located within the city limits, during normal business hours, with or without 
prior notice, and to examine operating practices of any carriage company to ensure continuous 
compliance with this chapter. 
(b) ?The chief of police shall have the authority to remove from operation upon the streets of the city any 
horse-drawn carriage which does not meet the requirements of this chapter, and may prohibit 
operation of the carriage until deficiencies have been corrected. Any person dissatisfied with the 
decision of the chief of police shall have the right of appeal to the city manager. Any such appeal 
may be submitted in writing to the city manager within seven (7) days from the date that the decision 
by the chief of police is rendered. The decision of the city manager is final. 
(c) ?Operators and agents of the carriage company and passengers shall comply with all city ordinances 
and state and federal laws which govern the treatment of animals, including horses, mules or other 
oxen of burden. Failure to comply with this chapter can result in revocation of the business permit 
and punishment at the discretion of the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11069. - Embarkation rotation slots. 
(a) ?Definition of rotation slots. A rotation slot entitles the holder to one place in the embarkation queue 
for a sixty-month period from the date of the issuance of the rotation slot, as follows: if there are two 
(2) operators who hold one rotation slot each, then each operator will alternate embarkation 
departures on an equal, consecutive basis. 
(b) ?Fees associated with rotation slots. All fees shall be assessed annually beginning January 1 in an 
amount determined by the sealed-bid procurement process set forth in paragraph (e) below with the 
minimum annual bid being in the amount determined by city council. 
(c) ?Carriage tours subject to the embarkation queuing system. All carriage tours that depart from the 
Marina Parking Lot are subject to the rules and regulations of the embarkation queuing system. 
(d) ?Carriage tours exempt from the embarkation queuing system. Point-to-point transportation which 
originates and terminates at locations other than the Marina Parking Lot are exempt from the 
queuing system. Special events as defined in this chapter and as approved by the city manager or 
his designee are exempt from the queuing system. 
(e) ?Allocation of rotation slots. There will be two (2) slots made available for purchase by bona fide 
carriage tour companies (one per company) at an annual fee determined by sealed-bid procurement 
process as set forth herein. Effective on the first day of October, 2006, and on each fifth year 
thereafter on the first business day of October, the city will conduct a sealed-bid procurement 
process for the purchase of the two (2) rotation slots (one per bona fide carriage tour company) for 
the ensuing sixty-month period beginning January 1. The sealed-bid shall be the annual fee for the 
embarkation rotation slot for the sixty-month period beginning the following January 1. City council 
shall determine the minimum bid for the annual fee, which shall be stated in the published 
procurement notice. Should either of the companies cease to operate for a period of more than sixty 
(60) consecutive days, the rotation slot shall be forfeited and a bid process as described herein shall 
take place. The high bidder in that process shall be awarded the rotation slot for the period remaining 
on the initial award. 
(f) ?Administration of rotation slots. Each carriage company shall be issued, and shall comply with, the 
document entitled "Slot Rotation System Standard Operating Procedure" as amended by the tour 
vehicle coordinator from time to time. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-10-05, 4-26-05; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-
28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11070. - Enforcement. 
    The city manager shall designate the appropriate agency within city government to enforce the 
enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. Violations of this chapter shall carry a fine of not less than 
one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per occurrence. Tour 
operators or guides may contest their citations in municipal court. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


ARTICLE E. - WALKING TOURS FOR HIRE 


Sec. 7-11071. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms mean: 
    City: A municipal corporation; the definition to include all areas within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Company: The holder of a license to operate a walking tour business under the provisions of this 
chapter whether a person, firm, partnership or corporation. 
    Inspector: The individual employee or department of the city charged with the responsibility for 
administering and enforcing this chapter. 
    License: The right and privilege granted by the city for operation of a business incorporating the use 
of one or more walking tours within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Street: Means and includes any street, alley, lane, avenue, court or public place or thoroughfare in 
the city. 
    Touring: Operation of a walking tour for hire where the primary purpose is to walk by and see historic 
and architectural sites, cultural attractions, or scenic areas. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11072. - Licensing of walking tour companies. 
(a) ?Business license required. No person, firm or corporation shall operate a business involving the use 
of one or more walking tour companies for hire upon the streets of the city unless a license for such 
business has first been granted by the city. 
(b) ?Fixed place of business. Each walking tour company, as a condition for holding a license under the 
provisions of this chapter, shall establish and maintain a fixed headquarters on public or private 
property for the operation of the company's business. The headquarters shall conform to the 
ordinances of the city. 
(c) ?Failure to comply. Any applicant who fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter shall not 
be issued or reissued a business license until proof of compliance is presented by the applicant and 
certified by the tour coordinator, police, or codes enforcement officer. All of the requirements of this 
chapter both serve as conditions for issuance of a license and apply to the business once 
operational. 
(d) ?Suspension of license. The city manager or designated official may temporarily suspend the 
business license of any walking tour company for violation of any provision of this ordinance. The 
walking tour company may appeal any such suspension to city council provided a written appeal has 
been submitted to the city manager within seven (7) days of the city manager's decision. 
(e) ?Limitations on business licenses. No more than six (6) bona fide walking tour companies shall be 
licensed to operate in the city. 
(f) ?Determination of bona fide operator status. The city manager shall determine whether a company 
that applies for a walking tour operator's license is, indeed a stand-alone company, with separate 
ownership, management, and equipment. Existing walking tour companies shall not be given a 
license to operate for a new company created in name only. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11073. - Insurance. 
(a) ?Any company offering walking tours in the City of Beaufort shall be required to provide proof of 
insurance at the time of business license application and upon request by any inspecting agent of 
the City of Beaufort. 
(b) ?Insurance requirements shall be set by city council. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11074. - General operating regulations. 
(a) ?The guide and guests of a walking tour shall neither trespass on private property nor block streets 
or access to driveways. The tour company shall be responsible for collection and removal of all trash 
generated by guests. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful to consume or transport alcoholic beverages while participating in any walking 
tour. 
(c) ?A guide may refuse service to any potential customer who appears to be impaired or disorderly. 
(d) ?Walking tours shall not be operated in adverse weather conditions as determined by the tour 
coordinator. 
(e) ?Speaker phones and amplification devices are prohibited on walking tours. All narration shall 
conform to the city noise ordinance. 
(f) ?All walking tours shall be limited to twenty (20) guests. 
(g) ?No animals shall be permitted on tours except service animals. 
(h) ?Any person conducting a walking tour must be certified by the City of Beaufort as a licensed tour 
guide. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11075. - Hours of operation. 
    Walking tours for hire shall be operated on the streets of the city only as follows: 
(1) ?Monday through Saturday, 9:30 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. in residential areas (8:30 p.m. in the core 
commercial district). 
(2) ?Sundays, Christmas, and Thanksgiving, 12:00 noon to 6:00 p.m. 
(3) ?No tour may commence after 7:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday or after 5:00 p.m. on 
Sundays, Christmas and Thanksgiving. 
(4) ?Any walking tour which will end later than one-half (½) hour after sunset or commences after 
sunset shall require that the tour operator must provide flashlights (or other device) to make the 
tour visible to traffic in any areas where the tour group is unable to use sidewalks or designated 
crosswalks. A minimum of one device will be provided for every three (3) people in the tour. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-03-08, 2-12-08; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11076. - Special events. 
    The city manager or designee may approve exceptions to this chapter regarding routes, maximum 
number of guests, and hours for special events. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


Sec. 7-11077. - Enforcement. 
    The city manager shall designate the appropriate agency within city government to enforce the 
enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. Violations of this chapter shall carry a fine of not less than 
one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per occurrence. Tour 
operators or guides may contest their citations in municipal court. 
(Ord. No. O-13-04, 6-8-04; Ord. No. O-28-11, 9-27-11) 


ARTICLE F. - BOAT TOURS FOR HIRE 


Sec. 7-11078. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms mean: 
    City: A municipal corporation; the definition to include all areas within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Company: The holder of a license to operate a boat tour business under the provisions of this 
chapter whether a person, firm, partnership, or corporation. 
    Contractor: The person, firm, partnership or corporation under contract by the city to operate the 
facilities and concessions at the city marina property. 
    Inspector: The individual employee or department of the city charged with the responsibility for 
administering and enforcing this chapter. 
    License: The right and privilege granted by the city for operation of a business incorporating the use
